	CHAPTER I
	"Well, Prince, so Genoa and Lucca are now just family estates of theuonapartes. But I warn you, if you don't tell me that this means war,f you still try to defend the infamies and horrors perpetrated byhat Antichrist- I really believe he is Antichrist- I will haveothing more to do with you and you are no longer my friend, no longery 'faithful slave,' as you call yourself! 	It was in July, 1805, and the speaker was the well-known Annaavlovna Scherer, maid of honor and favorite of the Empress Maryaedorovna. Our graciousovereign recognizes his high vocation and will be true to it. That ishe one thing I have faith in! 	"Her father is very rich and stingy. He lives in the country. Hes the well-known Prince Bolkonski who had to retire from the armynder the late Emperor, and was nicknamed 'the King of Prussia.' He isery clever but eccentric, and a bore. The poor girl is verynhappy. She has a brother; I think you know him, he married Liseeinen lately. 	CHAPTER XXV

	CHAPTER I
	In October, 1805, a Russian army was occupying the villages andowns of the Archduchy of Austria, and yet other regiments freshlyrriving from Russia were settling near the fortress of Braunau andurdening the inhabitants on whom they were quartered. Braunau was theeadquarters of the commander-in-chief, Kutuzov.
	On October 11, 1805, one of the infantry regiments that had justeached Braunau had halted half a mile from the town, waiting to benspected by the commander in chief. Despite the un-Russian appearancef the locality and surroundings- fruit gardens, stone fences, tiledoofs, and hills in the distance- and despite the fact that thenhabitants (who gazed with curiosity at the soldiers) were notussians, the regiment had just the appearance of any Russian regimentreparing for an inspection anywhere in the heart of Russia.
	On the evening of the last day's march an order had been receivedhat the commander in chief would inspect the regiment on the march.hough the words of the order were not clear to the regimentalommander, and the question arose whether the troops were to be inarching order or not, it was decided at a consultation between theattalion commanders to present the regiment in parade order, on therinciple that it is always better to "bow too low than not bow lownough." 	CHAPTER III

	CHAPTER IV
	The Pavlograd Hussars were stationed two miles from Braunau. Thequadron in which Nicholas Rostov served as a cadet was quartered inhe German village of Salzeneck. 	CHAPTER IX
	Pursued by the French army of a hundred thousand men under theommand of Bonaparte, encountering a population that was unfriendly tot, losing confidence in its allies, suffering from shortness ofupplies, and compelled to act under conditions of war unlike anythinghat had been foreseen, the Russian army of thirty-five thousand menommanded by Kutuzov was hurriedly retreating along the Danube,topping where overtaken by the enemy and fighting rearguard actionsnly as far as necessary to enable it to retreat without losing itseavy equipment. 	On the twenty-eighth of October Kutuzov with his army crossed to theeft bank of the Danube and took up a position for the first time withhe river between himself and the main body of the French. 	CHAPTER X

	CHAPTER XIV
	On November 1 Kutuzov had received, through a spy, news that thermy he commanded was in an almost hopeless position. The spy reportedhat the French, after crossing the bridge at Vienna, were advancingn immense force upon Kutuzov's line of communication with theroops that were arriving from Russia. 	Kutuzov chose this latter course.
	The French, the spy reported, having crossed the Vienna bridge, weredvancing by forced marches toward Znaim, which lay sixty-six milesff on the line of Kutuzov's retreat. 	A truce was Kutuzov's sole chance of gaining time, givingagration's exhausted troops some rest, and letting the transportnd heavy convoys (whose movements were concealed from the French)dvance if but one stage nearer Znaim. 	                               Schonbrunn, 25th Brumaire, 1805,
	                                at eight o'clock in the morning
	To PRINCE MURAT,
	I cannot find words to express to you my displeasure. You commandnly my advance guard, and have no right to arrange an armisticeithout my order. You are causing me to lose the fruits of a campaign.reak the armistice immediately and march on the enemy. 	The Russian Emperor's aide-de-camp is an impostor. Officers areothing when they have no powers; this one had none.... Theustrians let themselves be tricked at the crossing of the Viennaridge, you are letting yourself be tricked by an aide-de-camp ofhe Emperor.

	CHAPTER I
	Prince Vasili was not a man who deliberately thought out hislans. Still less did he think of injuring anyone for his owndvantage. He was merely a man of the world who had got on and to whometting on had become a habit. Schemes and devices for which heever rightly accounted to himself, but which formed the wholenterest of his life, were constantly shaping themselves in hisind, arising from the circumstances and persons he met. He did not, for instance, say to himself:This man now has influence, I must gain his confidence and friendshipnd through him obtain a special grant." Nor did he say to himself:Pierre is a rich man, I must entice him to marry my daughter and lende the forty thousand rubles I need." But when he came across camecross a man of position his instinct immediately told him that thisan could be useful, and without any premeditation Prince Vasiliook the first opportunity to gain his confidence, flatter him, becomentimate with him, and finally make his request.
	He had Pierre at hand in Moscow and procured for him anppointment as Gentleman of the Bedchamber, which at that timeonferred the status of Councilor of State, and insisted on theoung man accompanying him to Petersburg and staying at his house.ith apparent absent-mindedness, yet with unhesitating assurancehat he was doing the right thing, Prince Vasili did everything to getierre to marry his daughter. 	CHAPTER III

	CHAPTER VIII
	The day after Rostov had been to see Boris, a review was held of theustrian and Russian troops, both those freshly arrived from Russiand those who had been campaigning under Kutuzov. 	CHAPTER XI

One wheel slowly moved, another was set in motion, and third, and wheels began to revolve faster and faster, levers andogwheels to work, chimes to play, figures to pop out, and the handso advance with regular motion as a result of all that activity.
	Just as in the mechanism of a clock, so in the mechanism of theilitary machine, an impulse once given leads to the final result; andust as indifferently quiescent till the moment when motion isransmitted to them are the parts of the mechanism which the impulseas not yet reached. Wheels creak on their axles as the cogs engagene another and the revolving pulleys whirr with the rapidity of theirovement, but a neighboring wheel is as quiet and motionless as thought were prepared to remain so for a hundred years; but the momentomes when the lever catches it and obeying the impulse that wheelegins to creak and joins in the common motion the result and aim ofhich are beyond its ken.
	Just as in a clock, the result of the complicated motion ofnnumerable wheels and pulleys is merely a slow and regular movementf the hands which show the time, so the result of all the complicateduman activities of 160,000 Russians and French- all their passions,esires, remorse, humiliations, sufferings, outbursts of pride,ear, and enthusiasm- was only the loss of the battle of Austerlitz,he so-called battle of the three Emperors- that is to say, a slowovement of the hand on the dial of human history.

	CHAPTER XIV
	At five in the morning it was still quite dark. 	A soldier on the march is hemmed in and borne along by hisegiment as much as a sailor is by his ship. However far he hasalked, whatever strange, unknown, and dangerous places he reaches,ust as a sailor is always surrounded by the same decks, masts, andigging of his ship, so the soldier always has around him the sameomrades, the same ranks, the same sergeant major Ivan Mitrich, theame company dog Jack, and the same commanders. 	CHAPTER XIX
	On the Pratzen Heights, where he had fallen with the flagstaff inis hand, lay Prince Andrew Bolkonski bleeding profusely andnconsciously uttering a gentle, piteous, and childlike moan.
	Toward evening he ceased moaning and became quite still. He didot know how long his unconsciousness lasted. Suddenly he again felthat he was alive and suffering from a burning, lacerating pain in hisead.
	"Where is it, that lofty sky that I did not know till now, but sawoday?" was his first thought. "And I did not know this sufferingither," he thought. "Yes, I did not know anything, anything at allill now. But where am I?"
	He listened and heard the sound of approaching horses, and voicespeaking French. He opened his eyes. Above him again was the sameofty sky with clouds that had risen and were floating still higher,nd between them gleamed blue infinity. He did not turn his head andid not see those who, judging by the sound of hoofs and voices, hadidden up and stopped near him.
	It was Napoleon accompanied by two aides-de-camp. Bonaparte ridingver the battlefield had given final orders to strengthen theatteries firing at the Augesd Dam and was looking at the killed andounded left on the field.
	"Fine men!" remarked Napoleon, looking at a dead Russianrenadier, who, with his face buried in the ground and a blackenedape, lay on his stomach with an already stiffened arm flung wide.
	"The ammunition for the guns in position is exhausted, Yourajesty," said an adjutant who had come from the batteries that wereiring at Augesd.
	"Have some brought from the reserve," said Napoleon, and having gonen a few steps he stopped before Prince Andrew, who lay on his backith the flagstaff that had been dropped beside him. (The flag hadlready been taken by the French as a trophy.)
	"That's a fine death!" said Napoleon as he gazed at Bolkonski.
	Prince Andrew understood that this was said of him and that it wasapoleon who said it. He heard the speaker addressed as Sire. But heeard the words as he might have heard the buzzing of a fly. Notnly did they not interest him, but he took no notice of them and atnce forgot them. His head was burning, he felt himself bleeding toeath, and he saw above him the remote, lofty, and everlasting sky. Henew it was Napoleon- his hero- but at that moment Napoleon seemedo him such a small, insignificant creature compared with what wasassing now between himself and that lofty infinite sky with thelouds flying over it. At that moment it meant nothing to him whoight be standing over him, or what was said of him; he was onlylad that people were standing near him and only wished that theyould help him and bring him back to life, which seemed to him soeautiful now that he had today learned to understand it soifferently. He collected all his strength, to stir and utter a sound.e feebly moved his leg and uttered a weak, sickly groan which arousedis own pity.
	"Ah! He is alive," said Napoleon. "Lift this young man up andarry him to the dressing station."
	Having said this, Napoleon rode on to meet Marshal Lannes, who,at in hand, rode up smiling to the Emperor to congratulate him on theictory.

	The first words he heard on coming to his senses were those of arench convoy officer, who said rapidly: "We must halt here: themperor will pass here immediately; it will please him to see theseentlemen prisoners."
	"There are so many prisoners today, nearly the whole Russian army,hat he is probably tired of them," said another officer.
	"All the same! They say this one is the commander of all the Emperorlexander's Guards," said the first one, indicating a Russianfficer in the white uniform of the Horse Guards.
	Bolkonski recognized Prince Repnin whom he had met in Petersburgociety. Beside him stood a lad of nineteen, also a wounded officer ofhe Horse Guards.
	Bonaparte, having come up at a gallop, stopped his horse.
	"Which is the senior?" he asked, on seeing the prisoners.
	They named the colonel, Prince Repnin.
	"You are the commander of the Emperor Alexander's regiment oforse Guards?" asked Napoleon.
	"I commanded a squadron," replied Repnin.
	"Your regiment fulfilled its duty honorably," said Napoleon.
	"The praise of a great commander is a soldier's highest reward,"aid Repnin.
	"I bestow it with pleasure," said Napoleon. "And who is that youngan beside you?"

	"He is a nervous, bilious subject," said Larrey, "and will notecover."

	CHAPTER II

	Next day, the third of March, soon after one o'clock, two hundrednd fifty members of the English Club and fifty guests were awaitinghe guest of honor and hero of the Austrian campaign, Princeagration, to dinner.

	CHAPTER IV
	Pierre sat opposite Dolokhov and Nicholas Rostov. As usual, he atend drank much, and eagerly. But those who knew him intimately noticedhat some great change had come over him that day. 	CHAPTER I

	CHAPTER XV

	CHAPTER I

	CHAPTER VII
	Nearly two years before this, in 1808, Pierre on returning toetersburg after visiting his estates had involuntarily foundimself in a leading position among the Petersburg Freemasons. 	In the second category Pierre reckoned himself and others likeim, seeking and vacillating, who had not yet found in Freemasonry atraight and comprehensible path, but hoped to do so.

	"For the dissemination of pure truth and to secure the triumph ofirtue," he read, "we must cleanse men from prejudice, diffuserinciples in harmony with the spirit of the times, undertake theducation of the young, unite ourselves in indissoluble bonds with theisest men, boldly yet prudently overcome superstitions, infidelity,nd folly, and form of those devoted to us a body linked together bynity of purpose and possessed of authority and power.

	"The whole plan of our order should be based on the idea ofreparing men of firmness and virtue bound together by unity ofonviction- aiming at the punishment of vice and folly, andatronizing talent and virtue: raising worthy men from the dust andttaching them to our Brotherhood. In a word, weust found a form of government holding universal sway, which shoulde diffused over the whole world without destroying the bonds ofitizenship, and beside which all other governments can continue inheir customary course and do everything except what impedes the greatim of our order, which is to obtain for virtue the victory over vice.his aim was that of Christianity itself. It taught men to be wise andood and for their own benefit to follow the example and instructionf the best and wisest men.
	"At that time, when everything was plunged in darkness, preachinglone was of course sufficient. The novelty of Truth endowed herith special strength, but now we need much more powerful methods.t is now necessary that man, governed by his senses, should find inirtue a charm palpable to those senses. It is impossible to eradicatehe passions; but we must strive to direct them to a noble aim, and its therefore necessary that everyone should be able to satisfy hisassions within the limits of virtue. 	"As soon as we have a certain number of worthy men in every state,ach of them again training two others and all being closely united,verything will be possible for our order, which has already in secretccomplished much for the welfare of mankind."
	This speech not only made a strong impression, but createdxcitement in the lodge. 	*The Illuminati sought to substitute republican for monarchicalnstitutions.
	At the end of the meeting the Grand Master with irony and ill-willeproved Bezukhov for his vehemence and said it was not love of virtuelone, but also a love of strife that had moved him in the dispute.ierre did not answer him and asked briefly whether his proposal woulde accepted. 	CHAPTER VIII
	Again Pierre was overtaken by the depression he so dreaded. Forhree days after the delivery of his speech at the lodge he lay on aofa at home receiving no one and going nowhere.

	Moscow, 17th November

	Petersburg, 23rd November

	CHAPTER IX
	At that time, as always happens, the highest society that met atourt and at the grand balls was divided into several circles, eachith its own particular tone. 	*"That's a superb animal."
	*[2] "Of a charming woman, as witty as she is lovely."
	Pierre was just the husband needed for a brilliant society woman. 	Among the many young men who frequented her house every day, Borisrubetskoy, who had already achieved great success in the service, washe most intimate friend of the Bezukhov household since Helene'seturn from Erfurt. 	"No, now that she has become a bluestocking she has finallyenounced her former infatuations," he told himself. 	CHAPTER XI
	The Rostovs' monetary affairs had not improved during the twoears they had spent in the country.
	Though Nicholas Rostov had kept firmly to his resolution and wastill serving modestly in an obscure regiment, spendingomparatively little, the way of life at Otradnoe- Mitenka'sanagement of affairs, in particular- was such that the debtsnevitably increased every year. The only resource obviouslyresenting itself to the old count was to apply for an officialost, so he had come to Petersburg to look for one and also, as heaid, to let the lassies enjoy themselves for the last time.
	Soon after their arrival in Petersburg Berg proposed to Vera and wasccepted.

	In the Finnish war he also managed to distinguish himself. He hadicked up the scrap of a grenade that had killed an aide-de-camptanding near the commander in chief and had taken it to hisommander. In our times that isorth something, isn't it? But above all, she is a handsome, estimableirl, and she loves me..."
	Berg blushed and smiled.
	"And I love her, because her character is sensible and very good.ow the other sister, though they are the same family, is quiteifferent- an unpleasant character and has not the samentelligence. 	CHAPTER I
	The Bible legend tells us that the absence of labor- idleness- was aondition of the first man's blessedness before the Fall. Fallen manas retained a love of idleness, but the curse weighs on the raceot only because we have to seek our bread in the sweat of ourrows, but because our moral nature is such that we cannot be bothdle and at ease. 	CHAPTER XIII

	CHAPTER I
	After Prince Andrews engagement to Natasha, Pierre without anypparent cause suddenly felt it impossible to go on living asefore. 	In Moscow as soon as he entered his huge house in which the fadednd fading princesses still lived, with its enormous retinue; asoon as, driving through the town, he saw the Iberian shrine withnnumerable tapers burning before the golden covers of the icons,he Kremlin Square with its snow undisturbed by vehicles, the sleighrivers and hovels of the Sivtsev Vrazhok, those old Moscovites whoesired nothing, hurried nowhere, and were ending their dayseisurely; when he saw those old Moscow ladies, the Moscow balls,nd the English Club, he felt himself at home in a quiet haven. 	Pierre was one of those retired gentlemen-in-waiting of whom thereere hundreds good-humoredly ending their days in Moscow.

	CHAPTER V

	CHAPTER I
	From the close of the year 1811 intensified arming and concentratingf the forces of Western Europe began, and in 1812 these forces-illions of men, reckoning those transporting and feeding the army-oved from the west eastwards to the Russian frontier, toward whichince 1811 Russian forces had been similarly drawn. On the twelfthf June, 1812, the forces of Western Europe crossed the Russianrontier and war began, that is, an event took place opposed touman reason and to human nature. Millions of men perpetratedgainst one another such innumerable crimes, frauds, treacheries,hefts, forgeries, issues of false money, burglaries, incendiarisms,nd murders as in whole centuries are not recorded in the annals ofll the law courts of the world, but which those who committed themid not at the time regard as being crimes.
	What produced this extraordinary occurrence? What were its causes?he historians tell us with naive assurance that its causes were therongs inflicted on the Duke of Oldenburg, the nonobservance of theontinental System, the ambition of Napoleon, the firmness oflexander, the mistakes of the diplomatists, and so on.
	Consequently, it would only have been necessary for Metternich,umyantsev, or Talleyrand, between a levee and an evening party, toave taken proper pains and written a more adroit note, or forapoleon to have written to Alexander: "My respected Brother, Ionsent to restore the duchy to the Duke of Oldenburg"- and thereould have been no war.
	We can understand that the matter seemed like that toontemporaries. It naturally seemed to Napoleon that the war wasaused by England's intrigues (as in fact he said on the island of St.elena). It naturally seemed to members of the English Parliament thathe cause of the war was Napoleon's ambition; to the Duke ofldenburg, that the cause of the war was the violence done to him;o businessmen that the cause of the way was the Continental Systemhich was ruining Europe; to the generals and old soldiers that thehief reason for the war was the necessity of giving themmployment; to the legitimists of that day that it was the need ofe-establishing les bons principes, and to the diplomatists of thatime that it all resulted from the fact that the alliance betweenussia and Austria in 1809 had not been sufficiently well concealedrom Napoleon, and from the awkward wording of Memorandum No. 178.t is natural that these and a countless and infinite quantity ofther reasons, the number depending on the endless diversity of pointsf view, presented themselves to the men of that day; but to us, toosterity who view the thing that happened in all its magnitude anderceive its plain and terrible meaning, these causes seemnsufficient. To us it is incomprehensible that millions ofhristian men killed and tortured each other either because Napoleonas ambitious or Alexander was firm, or because England's policy wasstute or the Duke of Oldenburg wronged. We cannot grasp whatonnection such circumstances have with the actual fact of slaughternd violence: why because the Duke was wronged, thousands of menrom the other side of Europe killed and ruined the people of Smolensknd Moscow and were killed by them.
	To us, their descendants, who are not historians and are not carriedway by the process of research and can therefore regard the eventith unclouded common sense, an incalculable number of causesresent themselves. The deeper we delve in search of these causeshe more of them we find; and each separate cause or whole series ofauses appears to us equally valid in itself and equally false byts insignificance compared to the magnitude of the events, and by itsmpotence- apart from the cooperation of all the other coincidentauses- to occasion the event. To us, the wish or objection of this orhat French corporal to serve a second term appears as much a cause asapoleon's refusal to withdraw his troops beyond the Vistula and toestore the duchy of Oldenburg; for had he not wished to serve, andad a second, a third, and a thousandth corporal and private alsoefused, there would have been so many less men in Napoleon's army andhe war could not have occurred.
	Had Napoleon not taken offense at the demand that he should withdraweyond the Vistula, and not ordered his troops to advance, there wouldave been no war; but had all his sergeants objected to serving aecond term then also there could have been no war. Nor could thereave been a war had there been no English intrigues and no Duke ofldenburg, and had Alexander not felt insulted, and had there not beenn autocratic government in Russia, or a Revolution in France and aubsequent dictatorship and Empire, or all the things that producedhe French Revolution, and so on. Without each of these causes nothingould have happened. So all these causes- myriads of causes- coincidedo bring it about. And so there was no one cause for thatccurrence, but it had to occur because it had to. Millions of men,enouncing their human feelings and reason, had to go from west toast to slay their fellows, just as some centuries previously hordesf men had come from the east to the west, slaying their fellows.
	The actions of Napoleon and Alexander, on whose words the eventeemed to hang, were as little voluntary as the actions of any soldierho was drawn into the campaign by lot or by conscription. Thisould not be otherwise, for in order that the will of Napoleon andlexander (on whom the event seemed to depend) should be carriedut, the concurrence of innumerable circumstances was needed withoutny one of which the event could not have taken place. It wasecessary that millions of men in whose hands lay the real power-he soldiers who fired, or transported provisions and guns- shouldonsent to carry out the will of these weak individuals, and shouldave been induced to do so by an infinite number of diverse andomplex causes.
	We are forced to fall back on fatalism as an explanation ofrrational events (that is to say, events the reasonableness ofhich we do not understand). The more we try to explain such events inistory reasonably, the more unreasonable and incomprehensible do theyecome to us.
	Each man lives for himself, using his freedom to attain his personalims, and feels with his whole being that he can now do or abstainrom doing this or that action; but as soon as he has done it, thatction performed at a certain moment in time becomes irrevocable andelongs to history, in which it has not a free but a predestinedignificance.
	There are two sides to the life of every man, his individual life,hich is the more free the more abstract its interests, and hislemental hive life in which he inevitably obeys laws laid down forim.
	Man lives consciously for himself, but is an unconsciousnstrument in the attainment of the historic, universal, aims ofumanity. A deed done is irrevocable, and its result coinciding inime with the actions of millions of other men assumes an historicignificance. The higher a man stands on the social ladder, the moreeople he is connected with and the more power he has over others, theore evident is the predestination and inevitability of his everyction.
	"The king's heart is in the hands of the Lord."
	A king is history's slave.
	History, that is, the unconscious, general, hive life of mankind,ses every moment of the life of kings as a tool for its own purposes.
	Though Napoleon at that time, in 1812, was more convinced thanver that it depended on him, verser (ou ne pas verser) le sang de seseuples*- as Alexander expressed it in the last letter he wrote him-e had never been so much in the grip of inevitable laws, whichompelled him, while thinking that he was acting on his ownolition, to perform for the hive life- that is to say, for history-hatever had to be performed.
	*"To shed (or not to shed) the blood of his peoples."
	The people of the west moved eastwards to slay their fellow men, andy the law of coincidence thousands of minute causes fitted in ando-ordinated to produce that movement and war: reproaches for theonobservance of the Continental System, the Duke of Oldenburg'srongs, the movement of troops into Prussia- undertaken (as iteemed to Napoleon) only for the purpose of securing an armed peace,he French Emperor's love and habit of war coinciding with hiseople's inclinations, allurement by the grandeur of the preparations,nd the expenditure on those preparations and the need of obtainingdvantages to compensate for that expenditure, the intoxicating honorse received in Dresden, the diplomatic negotiations which, in thepinion of contemporaries, were carried on with a sincere desire tottain peace, but which only wounded the self-love of both sides,nd millions and millions of other causes that adapted themselves tohe event that was happening or coincided with it.
	When an apple has ripened and falls, why does it fall? Because ofts attraction to the earth, because its stalk withers, because its dried by the sun, because it grows heavier, because the wind shakest, or because the boy standing below wants to eat it?
	Nothing is the cause. All this is only the coincidence of conditionsn which all vital organic and elemental events occur. And theotanist who finds that the apple falls because the cellular tissueecays and so forth is equally right with the child who stands underhe tree and says the apple fell because he wanted to eat it andrayed for it. Equally right or wrong is he who says that Napoleonent to Moscow because he wanted to, and perished because Alexanderesired his destruction, and he who says that an undermined hilleighing a million tons fell because the last navvy struck it forhe last time with his mattock. In historic events the so-called greaten are labels giving names to events, and like labels they have buthe smallest connection with the event itself.
	Every act of theirs, which appears to them an act of their own will,s in an historical sense involuntary and is related to the wholeourse of history and predestined from eternity.BK9|CH2
	CHAPTER II
	On the twenty-ninth of May Napoleon left Dresden, where he had spenthree weeks surrounded by a court that included princes, dukes, kings,nd even an emperor. Before leaving, Napoleon showed favor to themperor, kings, and princes who had deserved it, reprimanded the kingsnd princes with whom he was dissatisfied, presented pearls andiamonds of his own- that is, which he had taken from other kings-o the Empress of Austria, and having, as his historian tells us,enderly embraced the Empress Marie Louise- who regarded him as herusband, though he had left another wife in Paris- left her grieved byhe parting which she seemed hardly able to bear. 	*Old style.
	Next day, overtaking the army, he went in a carriage to theiemen, and, changing into a Polish uniform, he drove to the riverbankn order to select a place for the crossing.

	For him it was no new conviction that his presence in any part ofhe world, from Africa to the steppes of Muscovy alike, was enougho dumfound people and impel them to insane self-oblivion. He calledor his horse and rode to his quarters.

	CHAPTER III
	The Emperor of Russia had, meanwhile, been in Vilna for more than month. reviewing troops and holding maneuvers. 	CHAPTER IV

	CHAPTER XVI

	CHAPTER XVII

	CHAPTER XIX
	From the day when Pierre, after leaving the Rostovs' withatasha's grateful look fresh in his mind, had gazed at the comet thateemed to be fixed in the sky and felt that something new wasppearing on his own horizon- from that day the problem of theanity and uselessness of all earthly things, that had incessantlyormented him, no longer presented itself. 	CHAPTER I
	Napoleon began the war with Russia because he could not resist goingo Dresden, could not help having his head turned by the homage heeceived, could not help donning a Polish uniform and yielding tohe stimulating influence of a June morning, and could not refrainrom bursts of anger in the presence of Kurakin and then of Balashev.
	Alexander refused negotiations because he felt himself to beersonally insulted. Barclay de Tolly tried to command the army in theest way, because he wished to fulfill his duty and earn fame as areat commander. Rostov charged the French because he could notestrain his wish for a gallop across a level field; and in the sameay the innumerable people who took part in the war acted in accordith their personal characteristics, habits, circumstances, andims. They were moved by fear or vanity, rejoiced or were indignant,easoned, imagining that they knew what they were doing and did itf their own free will, but they all were involuntary tools ofistory, carrying on a work concealed from them but comprehensibleo us. Such is the inevitable fate of men of action, and the higherhey stand in the social hierarchy the less are they free.
	The actors of 1812 have long since left the stage, their personalnterests have vanished leaving no trace, and nothing remains ofhat time but its historic results.
	Providence compelled all these men, striving to attain personalims, to further the accomplishment of a stupendous result no one ofhem at all expected- neither Napoleon, nor Alexander, nor stilless any of those who did the actual fighting.
	The cause of the destruction of the French army in 1812 is clearo us now. No one will deny that that cause was, on the one hand,ts advance into the heart of Russia late in the season without anyreparation for a winter campaign and, on the other, the characteriven to the war by the burning of Russian towns and the hatred of theoe this aroused among the Russian people. But no one at the timeoresaw (what now seems so evident) that this was the only way an armyf eight hundred thousand men- the best in the world and led by theest general- could be destroyed in conflict with a raw army of halfts numerical strength, and led by inexperienced commanders as theussian army was. Not only did no one see this, but on the Russianide every effort was made to hinder the only thing that could saveussia, while on the French side, despite Napoleon's experience ando-called military genius, every effort was directed to pushing ono Moscow at the end of the summer, that is, to doing the very thinghat was bound to lead to destruction.
	In historical works on the year 1812 French writers are very fond ofaying that Napoleon felt the danger of extending his line, that heought a battle and that his marshals advised him to stop at Smolensk,nd of making similar statements to show that the danger of theampaign was even then understood. Russian authors are still fonder ofelling us that from the commencement of the campaign a Scythian warlan was adopted to lure Napoleon into the depths of Russia, andhis plan some of them attribute to Pfuel, others to a certainrenchman, others to Toll, and others again to Alexander himself-ointing to notes, projects, and letters which contain hints of such aine of action. But all these hints at what happened, both from therench side and the Russian, are advanced only because they fit inith the event. Had that event not occurred these hints would haveeen forgotten, as we have forgotten the thousands and millions ofints and expectations to the contrary which were current then butave now been forgotten because the event falsified them. There arelways so many conjectures as to the issue of any event that howevert may end there will always be people to say: "I said then that itould be so," quite forgetting that amid their innumerable conjecturesany were to quite the contrary effect.
	Conjectures as to Napoleon's awareness of the danger of extendingis line, and (on the Russian side) as to luring the enemy into theepths of Russia, are evidently of that kind, and only by muchtraining can historians attribute such conceptions to Napoleon andis marshals, or such plans to the Russian commanders. All the factsre in flat contradiction to such conjectures. During the whole periodf the war not only was there no wish on the Russian side to drawhe French into the heart of the country, but from their first entrynto Russia everything was done to stop them. And not only wasapoleon not afraid to extend his line, but he welcomed every steporward as a triumph and did not seek battle as eagerly as in formerampaigns, but very lazily.
	At the very beginning of the war our armies were divided, and ourole aim was to unite them, though uniting the armies was no advantagef we meant to retire and lure the enemy into the depths of theountry. Our Emperor joined the army to encourage it to defend everynch of Russian soil and not to retreat. The enormous Drissa campas formed on Pfuel's plan, and there was no intention of retiringarther. The Emperor reproached the commanders in chief for every stephey retired. He could not bear the idea of letting the enemy eveneach Smolensk, still less could he contemplate the burning of Moscow,nd when our armies did unite he was displeased that Smolensk wasbandoned and burned without a general engagement having been foughtnder its walls.
	So thought the Emperor, and the Russian commanders and people weretill more provoked at the thought that our forces were retreatingnto the depths of the country.
	Napoleon having cut our armies apart advanced far into the countrynd missed several chances of forcing an engagement. In August heas at Smolensk and thought only of how to advance farther, thoughs we now see that advance was evidently ruinous to him.
	The facts clearly show that Napoleon did not foresee the danger ofhe advance on Moscow, nor did Alexander and the Russian commandershen think of luring Napoleon on, but quite the contrary. The luringf Napoleon into the depths of the country was not the result of anylan, for no one believed it to be possible; it resulted from a mostomplex interplay of intrigues, aims, and wishes among those whoook part in the war and had no perception whatever of the inevitable,r of the one way of saving Russia. Everything came aboutortuitously. The armies were divided at the commencement of theampaign. We tried to unite them, with the evident intention of givingattle and checking the enemy's advance, and by this effort to unitehem while avoiding battle with a much stronger enemy, and necessarilyithdrawing the armies at an acute angle- we led the French on tomolensk. But we withdrew at an acute angle not only because therench advanced between our two armies; the angle became still morecute and we withdrew still farther, because Barclay de Tolly was annpopular foreigner disliked by Bagration (who would come hisommand), and Bagration- being in command of the second army- tried toostpone joining up and coming under Barclay's command as long as heould. 	CHAPTER V
	From Smolensk the troops continued to retreat, followed by thenemy. 	CHAPTER VI
	Among the innumerable categories applicable to the phenomena ofuman life one may discriminate between those in which substancerevails and those in which form prevails. To the latter- asistinguished from village, country, provincial, or even Moscowife- we may allot Petersburg life, and especially the life of itsalons. That life of the salons is unchanging. 	CHAPTER VII
	While this was taking place in Petersburg the French had alreadyassed Smolensk and were drawing nearer and nearer to Moscow.apoleon's historian Thiers, like other of his historians, trying toustify his hero says that he was drawn to the walls of Moscow againstis will. He is as right as other historians who look for thexplanation of historic events in the will of one man; he is asight as the Russian historians who maintain that Napoleon was drawno Moscow by the skill of the Russian commanders. Here besides the lawf retrospection, which regards all the past as a preparation forvents that subsequently occur, the law of reciprocity comes in,onfusing the whole matter. A good chessplayer having lost a game isincerely convinced that his loss resulted from a mistake he madend looks for that mistake in the opening, but forgets that at eachtage of the game there were similar mistakes and that none of hisoves were perfect. He only notices the mistake to which he paysttention, because his opponent took advantage of it. How much moreomplex than this is the game of war, which occurs under certainimits of time, and where it is not one will that manipulates lifelessbjects, but everything results from innumerable conflicts ofarious wills!

	CHAPTER IX
	Until Prince Andrew settled in Bogucharovo its owners had alwayseen absentees, and its peasants were of quite a different characterrom those of Bald Hills. They differed from them in speech, dress,nd disposition. They were called steppe peasants. One instance, which had occurred somewenty years before, was a movement among the peasants to emigrateo some unknown "warm rivers." Hundreds of peasants, among them theogucharovo folk, suddenly began selling their cattle and moving inhole families toward the southeast. As birds migrate to somewhereeyond the sea, so these men with their wives and children streamed tohe southeast, to parts where none of them had ever been. They set offn caravans, bought their freedom one by one or ran away, and drove oralked toward the "warm rivers." Many of them were punished, some sento Siberia, many died of cold and hunger on the road, many returned ofheir own accord, and the movement died down of itself just as itad sprung up, without apparent reason. But such undercurrents stillxisted among the people and gathered new forces ready to manifesthemselves just as strangely, unexpectedly, and at the same timeimply, naturally, and forcibly. 	CHAPTER XVII
	After the Emperor had left Moscow, life flowed on there in its usualourse, and its course was so very usual that it was difficult toemember the recent days of patriotic elation and ardor, hard toelieve that Russia was really in danger and that the members of thenglish Club were also sons of the Fatherland ready to sacrificeverything for it. 	CHAPTER XVIII

	CHAPTER XIX
	On the twenty-fourth of August the battle of the Shevardinoedoubt was fought, on the twenty-fifth not a shot was fired by eitheride, and on the twenty-sixth the battle of Borodino itself tooklace.
	Why and how were the battles of Shevardino and Borodino given andccepted? Why was the battle of Borodino fought? There was not theeast sense in it for either the French or the Russians. Its immediateesult for the Russians was, and was bound to be, that we were broughtearer to the destruction of Moscow- which we feared more thannything in the world; and for the French its immediate result washat they were brought nearer to the destruction of their wholermy- which they feared more than anything in the world. What theesult must be was quite obvious, and yet Napoleon offered and Kutuzovccepted that battle.
	If the commanders had been guided by reason, it would seem that itust have been obvious to Napoleon that by advancing thirteenundred miles and giving battle with a probability of losing a quarterf his army, he was advancing to certain destruction, and it must haveeen equally clear to Kutuzov that by accepting battle and risking theoss of a quarter of his army he would certainly lose Moscow. Forutuzov this was mathematically clear, as it is that if when playingraughts I have one man less and go on exchanging, I shall certainlyose, and therefore should not exchange. When my opponent hasixteen men and I have fourteen, I am only one eighth weaker thane, but when I have exchanged thirteen more men he will be three timess strong as I am.
	Before the battle of Borodino our strength in proportion to therench was about as five to six, but after that battle it was littleore than one to two: previously we had a hundred thousand against aundred and twenty thousand; afterwards little more than fiftyhousand against a hundred thousand. Yet the shrewd and experiencedutuzov accepted the battle, while Napoleon, who was said to be aommander of genius, gave it, losing a quarter of his army andengthening his lines of communication still more. If it is saidhat he expected to end the campaign by occupying Moscow as he hadnded a previous campaign by occupying Vienna, there is muchvidence to the contrary. Napoleon's historians themselves tell ushat from Smolensk onwards he wished to stop, knew the danger of hisxtended position, and knew that the occupation of Moscow would not behe end of the campaign, for he had seen at Smolensk the state inhich Russian towns were left to him, and had not received a singleeply to his repeated announcements of his wish to negotiate.
	In giving and accepting battle at Borodino, Kutuzov actednvoluntarily and irrationally. But later on, to fit what hadccurred, the historians provided cunningly devised evidence of theoresight and genius the generals who, of all the blind tools ofistory were the most enslaved and involuntary.
	The ancients have left us model heroic poems in which the heroesurnish the whole interest of the story, and we are still unable toccustom ourselves to the fact that for our epoch histories of thatind are meaningless.
	On the other question, how the battle of Borodino and thereceding battle of Shevardino were fought, there also exists aefinite and well-known, but quite false, conception. All theistorians describe the affair as follows:
	The Russian army, they say, in its retreat from Smolensk soughtut for itself the best position for a general engagement and founduch a position at Borodino.
	The Russians, they say, fortified this position in advance on theeft of the highroad (from Moscow to Smolensk) and almost at a rightngle to it, from Borodino to Utitsa, at the very place where theattle was fought.
	In front of this position, they say, a fortified outpost was setp on the Shevardino mound to observe the enemy. On the twenty-fourth,e are told, Napoleon attacked this advanced post and took it, and, onhe twenty-sixth, attacked the whole Russian army, which was inosition on the field of Borodino.
	So the histories say, and it is all quite wrong, as anyone who careso look into the matter can easily convince himself.
	The Russians did not seek out the best position but, on theontrary, during the retreat passed many positions better thanorodino. They did not stop at any one of these positions becauseutuzov did not wish to occupy a position he had not himself chosen,ecause the popular demand for a battle had not yet expressed itselftrongly enough, and because Miloradovich had not yet arrived with theilitia, and for many other reasons. The fact is that otherositions they had passed were stronger, and that the position atorodino (the one where the battle was fought), far from being strong,as no more a position than any other spot one might find in theussian Empire by sticking a pin into the map at hazard.
	Not only did the Russians not fortify the position on the field oforodino to the left of, and at a right angle to, the highroad (thats, the position on which the battle took place), but never till thewenty-fifth of August, 1812, did they think that a battle might beought there. This was shown first by the fact that there were nontrenchments there by the twenty fifth and that those begun on thewenty-fifth and twenty-sixth were not completed, and secondly, by theosition of the Shevardino Redoubt. That redoubt was quite senselessn front of the position where the battle was accepted. Why was itore strongly fortified than any other post? And why were allfforts exhausted and six thousand men sacrificed to defend it tillate at night on the twenty-fourth? A Cossack patrol would haveufficed to observe the enemy. Thirdly, as proof that the positionn which the battle was fought had not been foreseen and that thehevardino Redoubt was not an advanced post of that position, weave the fact that up to the twenty-fifth, Barclay de Tolly andagration were convinced that the Shevardino Redoubt was the leftlank of the position, and that Kutuzov himself in his report, writtenn hot haste after the battle, speaks of the Shevardino Redoubt as theeft flank of the position. It was much later, when reports on theattle of Borodino were written at leisure, that the incorrect andxtraordinary statement was invented (probably to justify the mistakesf a commander in chief who had to be represented as infallible)hat the Shevardino Redoubt was an advanced post- whereas in realityt was simply a fortified point on the left flank- and that the battlef Borodino was fought by us on an entrenched position previouslyelected, where as it was fought on a quite unexpected spot whichas almost unentrenched.
	The case was evidently this: a position was selected along the riverolocha- which crosses the highroad not at a right angle but at ancute angle- so that the left flank was at Shevardino, the right flankear the village of Novoe, and the center at Borodino at theonfluence of the rivers Kolocha and Voyna.
	To anyone who looks at the field of Borodino without thinking of howhe battle was actually fought, this position, protected by theiver Kolocha, presents itself as obvious for an army whose object waso prevent an enemy from advancing along the Smolensk road to Moscow.
	Napoleon, riding to Valuevo on the twenty-fourth, did not see (ashe history books say he did) the position of the Russians from Utitsao Borodino (he could not have seen that position because it did notxist), nor did he see an advanced post of the Russian army, but whileursuing the Russian rearguard he came upon the left flank of theussian position- at the Shevardino Redoubt- and unexpectedly forhe Russians moved his army across the Kolocha. And the Russians,ot having time to begin a general engagement, withdrew their lefting from the position they had intended to occupy and took up a newosition which had not been foreseen and was not fortified. Byrossing to the other side of the Kolocha to the left of the highroad,apoleon shifted the whole forthcoming battle from right to leftlooking from the Russian side) and transferred it to the plainetween Utitsa, Semenovsk, and Borodino- a plain no moredvantageous as a position than any other plain in Russia- and therehe whole battle of the twenty-sixth of August took place.
	Had Napoleon not ridden out on the evening of the twenty-fourth tohe Kolocha, and had he not then ordered an immediate attack on theedoubt but had begun the attack next morning, no one would haveoubted that the Shevardino Redoubt was the left flank of our andhe battle would have taken place where we expected it. In that casee should probably have defended the Shevardino Redoubt- our leftlank- still more obstinately. We should have attacked Napoleon in theenter or on the right, and the engagement would have taken place onhe twenty-fifth, in the position we intended and had fortified. Buts the attack on our left flank took place in the evening after theetreat of our rea guard (that is, immediately after the fight atridneva), and as the Russian commanders did not wish, or were notn time, to begin a general engagement then on the evening of thewenty-fourth, the first and chief action of the battle of Borodinoas already lost on the twenty-fourth, and obviously led to the lossf the one fought on the twenty-sixth.
	After the loss of the Shevardino Redoubt, we found ourselves onhe morning of the twenty-fifth without a position for our left flank,nd were forced to bend it back and hastily entrench it where ithanced to be.
	Not only was the Russian army on the twenty-sixth defended byeak, unfinished entrenchments, but the disadvantage of thatosition was increased by the fact that the Russian commanders- notaving fully realized what had happened, namely the loss of ourosition on the left flank and the shifting of the whole field ofhe forthcoming battle from right to left- maintained their extendedosition from the village of Novoe to Utitsa, and consequently hado move their forces from right to left during the battle. So itappened that throughout the whole battle the Russians opposed thentire French army launched against our left flank with but half asany men. (Poniatowski's action against Utitsa, and Uvarov's on theight flank against the French, were actions distinct from the mainourse of the battle.) So the battle of Borodino did not take place atll as (in an effort to conceal our commanders' mistakes even at theost of diminishing the glory due to the Russian army and people) itas been described. The battle of Borodino was not fought on ahosen and entrenched position with forces only slightly weaker thanhose of the enemy, but, as a result of the loss of the Shevardinoedoubt, the Russians fought the battle of Borodino on an open andlmost unentrenched position, with forces only half as numerous as therench; that is to say, under conditions in which it was not merelynthinkable to fight for ten hours and secure an indecisive result,ut unthinkable to keep an army even from complete disintegrationnd flight.BK10|CH20
	CHAPTER XX

	CHAPTER XXI
	Pierre stepped out of his carriage and, passing the toilingilitiamen, ascended the knoll from which, according to the doctor,he battlefield could be seen.
	It was about eleven o'clock. The sun shone somewhat to the leftnd behind him and brightly lit up the enormous panorama which, risingike an amphitheater, extended before him in the clear rarefiedtmosphere.
	From above on the left, bisecting that amphitheater, wound themolensk highroad, passing through a village with a white churchome five hundred paces in front of the knoll and below it. Here and there over the whole of that bluexpanse, to right and left of the forest and the road, smokingampfires could be seen and indefinite masses of troops- ours andhe enemy's. 	"I must ask someone who knows," he thought, and addressed an officerho was looking with curiosity at his huge unmilitary figure.

	CHAPTER XXVI

	CHAPTER XXVII
	On the twenty-fifth of August, so his historians tell us, Napoleonpent the whole day on horseback inspecting the locality,onsidering plans submitted to him by his marshals, and personallyiving commands to his generals.
	The original line of the Russian forces along the river Kolochaad been dislocated by the capture of the Shevardino Redoubt on thewenty-fourth, and part of the line- the left flank- had been drawnack. That part of the line was not entrenched and in front of ithe ground was more open and level than elsewhere. It was evident tonyone, military or not, that it was here the French should attack. Itould seem that not much consideration was needed to reach thisonclusion, nor any particular care or trouble on the part of themperor and his marshals, nor was there any need of that special andupreme quality called genius that people are so apt to ascribe toapoleon; yet the historians who described the event later and the menho then surrounded Napoleon, and he himself, thought otherwise.
	Napoleon rode over the plain and surveyed the locality with arofound air and in silence, nodded with approval or shook his headubiously, and without communicating to the generals around him therofound course of ideas which guided his decisions merely gave themis final conclusions in the form of commands. 	After giving these and other commands he returned to his tent, andhe dispositions for the battle were written down from his dictation.
	These dispositions, of which the French historians write withnthusiasm and other historians with profound respect, were asollows:
	At dawn the two new batteries established during the night on thelain occupied by the Prince d'Eckmuhl will open fire on thepposing batteries of the enemy.
	At the same time the commander of the artillery of the 1st Corps,eneral Pernetti, with thirty cannon of Campan's division and allhe howitzers of Dessaix's and Friant's divisions, will moveorward, open fire, and overwhelm with shellfire the enemy'sattery, against which will operate:
	        24 guns of the artillery of the Guards
	        30 guns of Campan's division
	and      8 guns of Friant's and Dessaix's divisions
	        --
	in all  62 guns.
	The commander of the artillery of the 3rd Corps, General Fouche,ill place the howitzers of the 3rd and 8th Corps, sixteen in all,n the flanks of the battery that is to bombard the entrenchment onhe left, which will have forty guns in all directed against it.
	General Sorbier must be ready at the first order to advance with allhe howitzers of the Guard's artillery against either one or otherf the entrenchments.
	During the cannonade Prince Poniatowski is to advance through theood on the village and turn the enemy's position.
	General Campan will move through the wood to seize the firstortification.
	After the advance has begun in this manner, orders will be givenn accordance with the enemy's movements.
	The cannonade on the left flank will begin as soon as the guns ofhe right wing are heard. The sharpshooters of Morand's division andf the vice-King's division will open a heavy fire on seeing thettack commence on the right wing.

	All this must be done in good order (le tout se fera avec ordre etethode) as far as possible retaining troops in reserve.
	   The Imperial Camp near Mozhaysk,
	   September, 6, 1812.
	These dispositions, which are very obscure and confused if onellows oneself to regard the arrangements without religious awe of hisenius, related to Napoleon's orders to deal with four points- fourifferent orders. Not one of these was, or could be, carried out.
	In the disposition it is said first that the batteries placed on thepot chosen by Napoleon, with the guns of Pernetti and Fouche; whichere to come in line with them, 102 guns in all, were to open fire andhower shells on the Russian fleches and redoubts. 	CHAPTER XXVIII
	Many historians say that the French did not win the battle oforodino because Napoleon had a cold, and that if he had not had aold the orders he gave before and during the battle would have beentill more full of genius and Russia would have been lost and the facef the world have been changed. To historians who believe thatussia was shaped by the will of one man- Peter the Great- and thatrance from a republic became an empire and French armies went toussia at the will of one man- Napoleon- to say that Russia remained aower because Napoleon had a bad cold on the twenty-fourth of Augustay seem logical and convincing.
	If it had depended on Napoleon's will to fight or not to fight theattle of Borodino, and if this or that other arrangement dependedn his will, then evidently a cold affecting the manifestation ofis will might have saved Russia, and consequently the valet whomitted to bring Napoleon his waterproof boots on the twenty-fourthould have been the savior of Russia. Along that line of thoughtuch a deduction is indubitable, as indubitable as the deductionoltaire made in jest (without knowing what he was jesting at) when heaw that the Massacre of St. Bartholomew was due to Charles IX'stomach being deranged. But to men who do not admit that Russia wasormed by the will of one man, Peter I, or that the French Empireas formed and the war with Russia begun by the will of one man,apoleon, that argument seems not merely untrue and irrational, butontrary to all human reality. To the question of what causes historicvents another answer presents itself, namely, that the course ofuman events is predetermined from on high- depends on the coincidencef the wills of all who take part in the events, and that a Napoleon'snfluence on the course of these events is purely external andictitious.
	Strange as at first glance it may seem to suppose that theassacre of St. Bartholomew was not due to Charles IX's will, thoughe gave the order for it and thought it was done as a result of thatrder; and strange as it may seem to suppose that the slaughter ofighty thousand men at Borodino was not due to Napoleon's will, thoughe ordered the commencement and conduct of the battle and thought itas done because he ordered it; strange as these suppositionsppear, yet human dignity- which tells me that each of us is, if notore at least not less a man than the great Napoleon- demands thecceptance of that solution of the question, and historicnvestigation abundantly confirms it.
	At the battle of Borodino Napoleon shot at no one and killed no one.hat was all done by the soldiers. Therefore it was not he whoilled people.
	The French soldiers went to kill and be killed at the battle oforodino not because of Napoleon's orders but by their own volition.he whole army- French, Italian, German, Polish, and Dutch- hungry,agged, and weary of the campaign, felt at the sight of an armylocking their road to Moscow that the wine was drawn and must berunk. Had Napoleon then forbidden them to fight the Russians, theyould have killed him and have proceeded to fight the Russians becauset was inevitable.
	When they heard Napoleon's proclamation offering them, asompensation for mutilation and death, the words of posterity aboutheir having been in the battle before Moscow, they cried "Vive'Empereur!" just as they had cried "Vive l'Empereur!" at the sight ofhe portrait of the boy piercing the terrestrial globe with a toytick, and just as they would have cried "Vive l'Empereur!" at anyonsense that might be told them. There was nothing left for them too but cry "Vive l'Empereur!" and go to fight, in order to get foodnd rest as conquerors in Moscow. So it was not because ofapoleon's commands that they killed their fellow men.
	And it was not Napoleon who directed the course of the battle, forone of his orders were executed and during the battle he did not knowhat was going on before him. So the way in which these peopleilled one another was not decided by Napoleon's will but occurredndependently of him, in accord with the will of hundreds of thousandsf people who took part in the common action. It only seemed toapoleon that it all took place by his will. And so the questionhether he had or had not a cold has no more historic interest thanhe cold of the least of the transport soldiers.
	Moreover, the assertion made by various writers that his cold washe cause of his dispositions not being as well planned as on formerccasions, and of his orders during the battle not being as good asreviously, is quite baseless, which again shows that Napoleon'sold on the twenty-sixth of August was unimportant.
	The dispositions cited above are not at all worse, but are evenetter, than previous dispositions by which he had won victories.is pseudo-orders during the battle were also no worse thanormerly, but much the same as usual. These dispositions and ordersnly seem worse than previous ones because the battle of Borodinoas the first Napoleon did not win. The profoundest and most excellentispositions and orders seem very bad, and every learned militaristriticizes them with looks oks importance, when they relate to aattle that has been lost, and the very worst dispositions andrders seem very good, and serious people fill whole volumes toemonstrate their merits, when they relate to a battle that has beenon.
	The dispositions drawn up by Weyrother for the battle ofusterlitz were a model of perfection for that kind of composition,ut still they were criticized- criticized for their veryerfection, for their excessive minuteness.
	Napoleon at the battle of Borodino fulfilled his office asepresentative of authority as well as, and even better than, at otherattles. He did nothing harmful to the progress of the battle; henclined to the most reasonable opinions, he made no confusion, didot contradict himself, did not get frightened or run away from theield of battle, but with his great tact and military experiencearried out his role of appearing to command, calmly and with dignity.BK10|CH29
	CHAPTER XXIX
	On returning from a second inspection of the lines, Napoleonemarked:

	CHAPTER XXXV

	CHAPTER XXXVI

	CHAPTER I
	Absolute continuity of motion is not comprehensible to the humanind. Laws of motion of any kind become comprehensible to man onlyhen he examines arbitrarily selected elements of that motion; butt the same time, a large proportion of human error comes from therbitrary division of continuous motion into discontinuous elements.here is a well known, so-called sophism of the ancients consisting inhis, that Achilles could never catch up with a tortoise he wasollowing, in spite of the fact that he traveled ten times as fasts the tortoise. By the time Achilles has covered the distance thateparated him from the tortoise, the tortoise has covered one tenth ofhat distance ahead of him: when Achilles has covered that tenth,he tortoise has covered another one hundredth, and so on forever.his problem seemed to the ancients insoluble. The absurd answer (thatchilles could never overtake the tortoise) resulted from this: thatotion was arbitrarily divided into discontinuous elements, whereashe motion both of Achilles and of the tortoise was continuous.
	By adopting smaller and smaller elements of motion we onlypproach a solution of the problem, but never reach it. Only when weave admitted the conception of the infinitely small, and theesulting geometrical progression with a common ratio of one tenth,nd have found the sum of this progression to infinity, do we reach solution of the problem.
	A modern branch of mathematics having achieved the art of dealingith the infinitely small can now yield solutions in other moreomplex problems of motion which used to appear insoluble.
	This modern branch of mathematics, unknown to the ancients, whenealing with problems of motion admits the conception of thenfinitely small, and so conforms to the chief condition of motionabsolute continuity) and thereby corrects the inevitable errorhich the human mind cannot avoid when it deals with separate elementsf motion instead of examining continuous motion.
	In seeking the laws of historical movement just the same thingappens. The movement of humanity, arising as it does from innumerablerbitrary human wills, is continuous.
	To understand the laws of this continuous movement is the aim ofistory. But to arrive at these laws, resulting from the sum of allhose human wills, man's mind postulates arbitrary and disconnectednits. The first method of history is to take an arbitrarilyelected series of continuous events and examine it apart from others,hough there is and can be no beginning to any event, for one eventlways flows uninterruptedly from another.
	The second method is to consider the actions of some one man- a kingr a commander- as equivalent to the sum of many individual wills;hereas the sum of individual wills is never expressed by the activityf a single historic personage.
	Historical science in its endeavor to draw nearer to truthontinually takes smaller and smaller units for examination. Butowever small the units it takes, we feel that to take any unitisconnected from others, or to assume a beginning of anyhenomenon, or to say that the will of many men is expressed by thections of any one historic personage, is in itself false.
	It needs no critical exertion to reduce utterly to dust anyeductions drawn from history. It is merely necessary to select somearger or smaller unit as the subject of observation- as criticism hasvery right to do, seeing that whatever unit history observes mustlways be arbitrarily selected.
	Only by taking infinitesimally small units for observation (theifferential of history, that is, the individual tendencies of men)nd attaining to the art of integrating them (that is, finding the sumf these infinitesimals) can we hope to arrive at the laws of history.
	The first fifteen years of the nineteenth century in Europeresent an extraordinary movement of millions of people. Men leaveheir customary pursuits, hasten from one side of Europe to the other,lunder and slaughter one another, triumph and are plunged in despair,nd for some years the whole course of life is altered and presents anntensive movement which first increases and then slackens. What washe cause of this movement, by what laws was it governed? asks theind of man.
	The historians, replying to this question, lay before us the sayingsnd doings of a few dozen men in a building in the city of Paris,alling these sayings and doings "the Revolution"; then they give aetailed biography of Napoleon and of certain people favorable orostile to him; tell of the influence some of these people had onthers, and say: that is why this movement took place and those arets laws.
	But the mind of man not only refuses to believe this explanation,ut plainly says that this method of explanation is fallacious,ecause in it a weaker phenomenon is taken as the cause of a stronger.he sum of human wills produced the Revolution and Napoleon, andnly the sum of those wills first tolerated and then destroyed them.
	"But every time there have been conquests there have beenonquerors; every time there has been a revolution in any statehere have been great men," says history. And, indeed, human reasoneplies: every time conquerors appear there have been wars, but thisoes not prove that the conquerors caused the wars and that it isossible to find the laws of a war in the personal activity of aingle man. Whenever I look at my watch and its hands point to ten, hear the bells of the neighboring church; but because the bellsegin to ring when the hands of the clock reach ten, I have no righto assume that the movement of the bells is caused by the positionf the hands of the watch.
	Whenever I see the movement of a locomotive I hear the whistle andee the valves opening and wheels turning; but I have no right toonclude that the whistling and the turning of wheels are the cause ofhe movement of the engine.
	The peasants say that a cold wind blows in late spring because theaks are budding, and really every spring cold winds do blow whenhe oak is budding. But though I do not know what causes the coldinds to blow when the oak buds unfold, I cannot agree with theeasants that the unfolding of the oak buds is the cause of the coldind, for the force of the wind is beyond the influence of the buds. Iee only a coincidence of occurrences such as happens with all thehenomena of life, and I see that however much and however carefully Ibserve the hands of the watch, and the valves and wheels of thengine, and the oak, I shall not discover the cause of the bellsinging, the engine moving, or of the winds of spring. To that Iust entirely change my point of view and study the laws of theovement of steam, of the bells, and of the wind. History must dohe same. And attempts in this direction have already been made.
	To study the laws of history we must completely change the subjectf our observation, must leave aside kings, ministers, and generals,nd the common, infinitesimally small elements by which the masses areoved. No one can say in how far it is possible for man to advancen this way toward an understanding of the laws of history; but its evident that only along that path does the possibility ofiscovering the laws of history lie, and that as yet not a millionthart as much mental effort has been applied in this direction byistorians as has been devoted to describing the actions of variousings, commanders, and ministers and propounding the historians' owneflections concerning these actions.BK11|CH2
	CHAPTER II

	For people accustomed to think that plans of campaign and battlesre made by generals- as any one of us sitting over a map in his studyay imagine how he would have arranged things in this or thatattle- the questions present themselves: Why did Kutuzov during theetreat not do this or that? The activity of aommander in chief does not all resemble the activity we imagine tourselves when we sit at case in our studies examining some campaignn the map, with a certain number of troops on this and that side in aertain known locality, and begin our plans from some given moment. commander in chief is never dealing with the beginning of any event-he position from which we always contemplate it. The commander inhief is always in the midst of a series of shifting events and soe never can at any moment consider the whole import of an eventhat is occurring. Moment by moment the event is imperceptibly shapingtself, and at every moment of this continuous, uninterruptedhaping of events the commander in chief is in the midst of a mostomplex play of intrigues, worries, contingencies, authorities,rojects, counsels, threats, and deceptions and is continually obligedo reply to innumerable questions addressed to him, which constantlyonflict with one another.
	Learned military authorities quite seriously tell us that Kutuzovhould have moved his army to the Kaluga road long before reachingili, and that somebody actually submitted such a proposal to him. But commander in chief, especially at a difficult moment, has alwaysefore him not one proposal but dozens simultaneously. And all theseroposals, based on strategics and tactics, contradict each other.
	A commander in chief's business, it would seem, is simply tohoose one of these projects. But even that he cannot do. Events andime do not wait. For instance, on the twenty-eighth it is suggestedo him to cross to the Kaluga road, but just then an adjutantallops up from Miloradovich asking whether he is to engage the Frenchr retire. An order must be given him at once, that instant. And therder to retreat carries us past the turn to the Kaluga road. Andfter the adjutant comes the commissary general asking where thetores are to be taken, and the chief of the hospitals asks wherehe wounded are to go, and a courier from Petersburg brings a letterrom the sovereign which does not admit of the possibility ofbandoning Moscow, and the commander in chief's rival, the man whos undermining him (and there are always not merely one but severaluch), presents a new project diametrically opposed to that of turningo the Kaluga road, and the commander in chief himself needs sleep andefreshment to maintain his energy and a respectable general who haseen overlooked in the distribution of rewards comes to complain,nd the inhabitants of the district pray to be defended, and anfficer sent to inspect the locality comes in and gives a report quiteontrary to what was said by the officer previously sent; and a spy, arisoner, and a general who has been on reconnaissance, all describehe position of the enemy's army differently. People accustomed toisunderstand or to forget these inevitable conditions of aommander in chief's actions describe to us, for instance, theosition of the army at Fili and assume that the commander in chiefould, on the first of September, quite freely decide whether tobandon Moscow or defend it; whereas, with the Russian army lesshan four miles from Moscow, no such question existed. 	CHAPTER III

	CHAPTER V
	At that very time, in circumstances even more important thanetreating without a battle, namely the evacuation and burning ofoscow, Rostopchin, who is usually represented as being the instigatorf that event, acted in an altogether different manner from Kutuzov.
	After the battle of Borodino the abandonment and burning of Moscowas as inevitable as the retreat of the army beyond Moscow withoutighting.

	The same thing that took place in Moscow had happened in all theowns and villages on Russian soil beginning with Smolensk, withouthe participation of Count Rostopchin and his broadsheets. 	The consciousness that this would be so and would always be so wasnd is present in the heart of every Russian. 	CHAPTER VI

	CHAPTER VII

	CHAPTER VIII

	CHAPTER XV
	Moscow's last day had come. It was a clear bright autumn day, aunday. The church bells everywhere were ringing for service, justs usual on Sundays. Nobody seemed yet to realize what awaited theity.

	CHAPTER XVI

	CHAPTER XIX
	Kutuzov's order to retreat through Moscow to the Ryazan road wasssued at night on the first of September.
	The first troops started at once, and during the night theyarched slowly and steadily without hurry.
