	CHAPTER XX
	Meanwhile Moscow was empty. There were still people in it, perhaps aiftieth part of its former inhabitants had remained, but it wasmpty. It was empty in the sense that a dying queenless hive is empty.
	In a queenless hive no life is left though to a superficial glancet seems as much alive as other hives.
	The bees circle round a queenless hive in the hot beams of theidday sun as gaily as around the living hives; from a distance itmells of honey like the others, and bees fly in and out in the sameay. But one has only to observe that hive to realize that there is noonger any life in it. The bees do not fly in the same way, themell and the sound that meet the beekeeper are not the same. To theeekeeper's tap on the wall of the sick hive, instead of the formernstant unanimous humming of tens of thousands of bees with theirbdomens threateningly compressed, and producing by the rapidibration of their wings an aerial living sound, the only reply is aisconnected buzzing from different parts of the deserted hive. Fromhe alighting board, instead of the former spirituous fragrant smellf honey and venom, and the warm whiffs of crowded life, comes an odorf emptiness and decay mingling with the smell of honey. There areo longer sentinels sounding the alarm with their abdomens raised, andeady to die in defense of the hive. There is no longer the measureduiet sound of throbbing activity, like the sound of boiling water,ut diverse discordant sounds of disorder. In and out of the hive longlack robber bees smeared with honey fly timidly and shiftily. They doot sting, but crawl away from danger. Formerly only bees laden withoney flew into the hive, and they flew out empty; now they fly outaden. The beekeeper opens the lower part of the hive and peers in.nstead of black, glossy bees- tamed by toil, clinging to onenother's legs and drawing out the wax, with a ceaseless hum of labor-hat used to hang in long clusters down to the floor of the hive,rowsy shriveled bees crawl about separately in various directionsn the floor and walls of the hive. Instead of a neatly glued floor,wept by the bees with the fanning of their wings, there is a floorittered with bits of wax, excrement, dying bees scarcely moving theiregs, and dead ones that have not been cleared away.
	The beekeeper opens the upper part of the hive and examines theuper. Instead of serried rows of bees sealing up every gap in theombs and keeping the brood warm, he sees the skillful complextructures of the combs, but no longer in their former state ofurity. All is neglected and foul. Black robber bees are swiftly andtealthily prowling about the combs, and the short home bees,hriveled and listless as if they were old, creep slowly about withoutrying to hinder the robbers, having lost all motive and all sensef life. Drones, bumblebees, wasps, and butterflies knock awkwardlygainst the walls of the hive in their flight. Here and there amonghe cells containing dead brood and honey an angry buzzing canometimes be heard. Here and there a couple of bees, by force of habitnd custom cleaning out the brood cells, with efforts beyond theirtrength laboriously drag away a dead bee or bumblebee without knowinghy they do it. In another corner two old bees are languidly fighting,r cleaning themselves, or feeding one another, without themselvesnowing whether they do it with friendly or hostile intent. In a thirdlace a crowd of bees, crushing one another, attack some victim andight and smother it, and the victim, enfeebled or killed, dropsrom above slowly and lightly as a feather, among the heap of corpses.he keeper opens the two center partitions to examine the brood cells.n place of the former close dark circles formed by thousands ofees sitting back to back and guarding the high mystery of generation,e sees hundreds of dull, listless, and sleepy shells of bees. Theyave almost all died unawares, sitting in the sanctuary they haduarded and which is now no more. They reek of decay and death. Only aew of them still move, rise, and feebly fly to settle on thenemy's hand, lacking the spirit to die stinging him; the rest areead and fall as lightly as fish scales. The beekeeper closes theive, chalks a mark on it, and when he has time tears out its contentsnd burns it clean.
	So in the same way Moscow was empty when Napoleon, weary, uneasy,nd morose, paced up and down in front of the Kammer-Kollezskiampart, awaiting what to his mind was a necessary, if but formal,bservance of the proprieties- a deputation.
	In various corners of Moscow there still remained a few peopleimlessly moving about, following their old habits and hardly aware ofhat they were doing.
	When with due circumspection Napoleon was informed that Moscow wasmpty, he looked angrily at his informant, turned away, and silentlyontinued to walk to and fro.
	"My carriage!" he said.
	He took his seat beside the aide-de-camp on duty and drove intohe suburb. "Moscow deserted!" he said to himself. "What an incrediblevent!"
	He did not drive into the town, but put up at an inn in theorogomilov suburb.

	CHAPTER XXIV
	On the evening of the first of September, after his interview withutuzov, Count Rostopchin had returned to Moscow mortified andffended because he had not been invited to attend the council of war,nd because Kutuzov had paid no attention to his offer to take part inhe defense of the city; amazed also at the novel outlook revealedo him at the camp, which treated the tranquillity of the capitalnd its patriotic fervor as not merely secondary but quiterrelevant and unimportant matters. Distressed, offended, andurprised by all this, Rostopchin had returned to Moscow. After suppere lay down on a sofa without undressing, and was awakened soonfter midnight by a courier bringing him a letter from Kutuzov. Thisetter requested the count to send police officers to guide the troopshrough the town, as the army was retreating to the Ryazan road beyondoscow. This was not news to Rostopchin. He had known that Moscowould be abandoned not merely since his interview the previous dayith Kutuzov on the Poklonny Hill but ever since the battle oforodino, for all the generals who came to Moscow after that battlead said unanimously that it was impossible to fight another battle,nd since then the government property had been removed every night,nd half the inhabitants had left the city with Rostopchin's ownermission. Yet all the same this information astonished and irritatedhe count, coming as it did in the form of a simple note with an orderrom Kutuzov, and received at night, breaking in on his beauty sleep.
	When later on in his memoirs Count Rostopchin explained hisctions at this time, he repeatedly says that he was then actuatedy two important considerations: to maintain tranquillity in Moscownd expedite the departure of the inhabitants. If one accepts thiswofold aim all Rostopchin's actions appear irreproachable. "Whyere the holy relics, the arms, ammunition, gunpowder, and stores oforn not removed? Why were thousands of inhabitants deceived intoelieving that Moscow would not be given up- and thereby ruined?"To presence the tranquillity of the city," explains Count Rostopchin.Why were bundles of useless papers from the government offices, andeppich's balloon and other articles removed?" "To leave the townmpty," explains Count Rostopchin. One need only admit that publicranquillity is in danger and any action finds a justification.
	All the horrors of the reign of terror were based only on solicitudeor public tranquillity.
	On what, then, was Count Rostopchin's fear for the tranquillity ofoscow based in 1812? What reason was there for assuming anyrobability of an uprising in the city? The inhabitants were leavingt and the retreating troops were filling it. Why should that causehe masses to riot?
	Neither in Moscow nor anywhere in Russia did anything resemblingn insurrection ever occur when the enemy entered a town. More thanen thousand people were still in Moscow on the first and second ofeptember, and except for a mob in the governor's courtyard, assembledhere at his bidding, nothing happened. It is obvious that there wouldave been even less reason to expect a disturbance among the people iffter the battle of Borodino, when the surrender of Moscow becameertain or at least probable, Rostopchin instead of exciting theeople by distributing arms and broadsheets had taken steps toemove all the holy relics, the gunpowder, munitions, and money, andad told the population plainly that the town would be abandoned.
	Rostopchin, though he had patriotic sentiments, was a sanguine andmpulsive man who had always moved in the highest administrativeircles and had no understanding at all of the people he supposedimself to be guiding. Ever since the enemy's entry into Smolensk head in imagination been playing the role of director of the populareeling of "the heart of Russia." Not only did it seem to him (as toll administrators) that he controlled the external actions ofoscow's inhabitants, but he also thought he controlled their mentalttitude by means of his broadsheets and posters, written in aoarse tone which the people despise in their own class and do notnderstand from those in authority. Rostopchin was so pleased with theine role of leader of popular feeling, and had grown so used to it,hat the necessity of relinquishing that role and abandoning Moscowithout any heroic display took him unawares and he suddenly felthe ground slip away from under his feet, so that he positively didot know what to do. Though he knew it was coming, he did not till theast moment wholeheartedly believe that Moscow would be abandoned, andid not prepare for it. The inhabitants left against his wishes. Ifhe government offices were removed, this was only done on theemand of officials to whom the count yielded reluctantly. He wasbsorbed in the role he had created for himself. As is often thease with those gifted with an ardent imagination, though he hadong known that Moscow would be abandoned he knew it only with hisntellect, he did not believe it in his heart and did not adaptimself mentally to this new position of affairs.
	All his painstaking and energetic activity (in how far it was usefulnd had any effect on the people is another question) had beenimply directed toward arousing in the masses his own feeling ofatriotic hatred of the French.
	But when events assumed their true historical character, whenxpressing hatred for the French in words proved insufficient, when itas not even possible to express that hatred by fighting a battle,hen self-confidence was of no avail in relation to the one questionefore Moscow, when the whole population streamed out of Moscow as onean, abandoning their belongings and proving by that negative actionll the depth of their national feeling, then the role chosen byostopchin suddenly appeared senseless. He unexpectedly felt himselfidiculous, weak, and alone, with no ground to stand on.
	When, awakened from his sleep, he received that cold, peremptoryote from Kutuzov, he felt the more irritated the more he felt himselfo blame. All that he had been specially put in charge of, the stateroperty which he should have removed, was still in Moscow and itas no longer possible to take the whole of it away.
	"Who is to blame for it? Who has let things come to such a pass?" heuminated. "Not I, of course. I had everything ready. I had Moscowirmly in hand. And this is what they have let it come to! Villains!raitors!" he thought, without clearly defining who the villains andraitors were, but feeling it necessary to hate those traitors whoeverhey might be who were to blame for the false and ridiculousosition in which he found himself.
	All that night Count Rostopchin issued orders, for which people cameo him from all parts of Moscow. Those about him had never seen theount so morose and irritable.
	"Your excellency, the Director of the Registrar's Department hasent for instructions... From the Consistory, from the Senate, fromhe University, from the Foundling Hospital, the Suffragan has sent...sking for information.... What are your orders about the Firerigade? From the governor of the prison... from the superintendent ofhe lunatic asylum..." All night long such announcements wereontinually being received by the count.
	To all these inquiries he gave brief and angry replies indicatinghat orders from him were not now needed, that the whole affair,arefully prepared by him, had now been ruined by somebody, and thathat somebody would have to bear the whole responsibility for all thatight happen.
	"Oh, tell that blockhead," he said in reply to the question from theegistrar's Department, "that he should remain to guard his documents.ow why are you asking silly questions about the Fire Brigade? Theyave horses, let them be off to Vladimir, and not leave them to therench."

	The French attributed the Fire of Moscow au patriotisme feroce deostopchine,* the Russians to the barbarity of the French. In reality,owever, it was not, and could not be, possible to explain the burningf Moscow by making any individual, or any group of people,esponsible for it. Moscow was burned because it found itself in aosition in which any town built of wood was bound to burn, quitepart from whether it had, or had not, a hundred and thirty inferiorire engines. Deserted Moscow had to burn as inevitably as a heap ofhavings has to burn on which sparks continually fall for severalays. A town built of wood, where scarcely a day passes withoutonflagrations when the house owners are in residence and a policeorce is present, cannot help burning when its inhabitants have leftt and it is occupied by soldiers who smoke pipes, make campfires ofhe Senate chairs in the Senate Square, and cook themselves mealswice a day. In peacetime it is only necessary to billet troops in theillages of any district and the number of fires in that districtmmediately increases. How much then must the probability of fire bencreased in an abandoned, wooden town where foreign troops areuartered. "Le patriotisme feroce de Rostopchine" and the barbarity ofhe French were not to blame in the matter. Moscow was set on firey the soldiers' pipes, kitchens, and campfires, and by thearelessness of enemy soldiers occupying houses they did not own. Evenf there was any arson (which is very doubtful, for no one had anyeason to burn the houses- in any case a troublesome and dangeroushing to do), arson cannot be regarded as the cause, for the samehing would have happened without any incendiarism.
	*To Rostopchin's ferocious patriotism.
	However tempting it might be for the French to blame Rostopchin'serocity and for Russians to blame the scoundrel Bonaparte, or latern to place an heroic torch in the hands of their own people, it ismpossible not to see that there could be no such direct cause ofhe fire, for Moscow had to burn as every village, factory, or houseust burn which is left by its owners and in which strangers arellowed to live and cook their porridge. Moscow was burned by itsnhabitants, it is true, but by those who had abandoned it and noty those who remained in it. Moscow when occupied by the enemy did notemain intact like Berlin, Vienna, and other towns, simply because itsnhabitants abandoned it and did not welcome the French with bread andalt, nor bring them the keys of the city.BK11|CH27
	CHAPTER XXVII
	The absorption of the French by Moscow, radiating starwise as itid, only reached the quarter where Pierre was staying by thevening of the second of September.
	After the last two days spent in solitude and unusual circumstances,ierre was in a state bordering on insanity. He was completelybsessed by one persistent thought. 	CHAPTER I
	In Petersburg at that time a complicated struggle was beingarried on with greater heat than ever in the highest circles, betweenhe parties of Rumyantsev, the French, Marya Fedorovna, the Tsarevich,nd others, drowned as usual by the buzzing of the court drones. 	CHAPTER II
	Anna Pavlovna's presentiment was in fact fulfilled. 	CHAPTER IV
	It is natural for us who were not living in those days to imaginehat when half Russia had been conquered and the inhabitants wereiceing to distant provinces, and one levy after another was beingaised for the defense of the fatherland, all Russians from thereatest to the least were solely engaged in sacrificing themselves,aving their fatherland, or weeping over its downfall. The tales andescriptions of that time without exception speak only of theelf-sacrifice, patriotic devotion, despair, grief, and the heroism ofhe Russians. But it was not really so. It appears so to us because weee only the general historic interest of that time and do not see allhe personal human interests that people had. Yet in reality thoseersonal interests of the moment so much transcend the generalnterests that they always prevent the public interest from being feltr even noticed. Most of the people at that time paid no attentiono the general progress of events but were guided only by theirrivate interests, and they were the very people whose activities athat period were most useful.

In historic events the rule forbidding us to eat of the fruit ofhe Tree of Knowledge is specially applicable. 	CHAPTER VI

	CHAPTER XII
	After the execution Pierre was separated from the rest of therisoners and placed alone in a small, ruined, and befouled church.

Andere we live, thank heaven, without offense. 	Sounds of crying and screaming came from somewhere in the distanceutside, and flames were visible through the cracks of the shed, butnside it was quiet and dark. 	CHAPTER XIII
	Twenty-three soldiers, three officers, and two officials wereonfined in the shed in which Pierre had been placed and where heemained for four weeks.
	When Pierre remembered them afterwards they all seemed misty figureso him except Platon Karataev, who always remained in his mind aost vivid and precious memory and the personification of everythingussian, kindly, and round. 	His face, despite its fine, rounded wrinkles, had an expression ofnnocence and youth, his voice was pleasant and musical. But the chiefeculiarity of his speech was its directness and appositeness. 	His physical strength and agility during the first days of hismprisonment were such that he seemed not to know what fatigue andickness meant. He could do everything, not very well but notadly. He baked, cooked, sewed, planed, and mended boots. He waslways busy, and only at night allowed himself conversation- ofhich he was fond- and songs. 	Having been taken prisoner and allowed his beard to grow, heeemed to have thrown off all that had been forced upon him-verything military and alien to himself- and had returned to hisormer peasant habits.
	"A soldier on leave- a shirt outside breeches," he would say.
	He did not like talking about his life as a soldier, though he didot complain, and often mentioned that he had not been flogged onceuring the whole of his army service. When he related anything itas generally some old and evidently precious memory of hisChristian" life, as he called his peasant existence. The proverbs, ofhich his talk was full, were for the most part not the coarse andndecent saws soldiers employ, but those folk sayings which takenithout a context seem so insignificant, but when used appositelyuddenly acquire a significance of profound wisdom.
	He would often say the exact opposite of what he had said on arevious occasion, yet both would be right. He would smile joyfully when listening to suchtories, now and then putting in a word or asking a question to makehe moral beauty of what he was told clear to himself. Karataev had nottachments, friendships, or love, as Pierre understood them, butoved and lived affectionately with everything life brought him inontact with, particularly with man- not any particular man, but thoseith whom he happened to be. He loved his dog, his comrades, therench, and Pierre who was his neighbor, but Pierre felt that in spitef Karataev's affectionate tenderness for him (by which henconsciously gave Pierre's spiritual life its due) he would notave grieved for a moment at parting from him. 	To all the other prisoners Platon Karataev seemed a most ordinaryoldier. They called him "little falcon" or "Platosha," chaffed himood-naturedly, and sent him on errands. 	Platon Karataev knew nothing by heart except his prayers. When heegan to speak he seemed not to know how he would conclude.
	Sometimes Pierre, struck by the meaning of his words, would askim to repeat them, but Platon could never recall what he had said aoment before, just as he never could repeat to Pierre the words ofis favorite song: native and birch tree and my heart is sick occurredn it, but when spoken and not sung, no meaning could be got out oft. He did not, and could not, understand the meaning of words apartrom their context. Every word and action of his was the manifestationf an activity unknown to him, which was his life. 	CHAPTER XIV
	When Princess Mary heard from Nicholas that her brother was with theostovs at Yaroslavl she at once prepared to go there, in spite of herunt's efforts to dissuade her- and not merely to go herself but toake her nephew with her. 	CHAPTER I
	Man's mind cannot grasp the causes of events in theirompleteness, but the desire to find those causes is implanted inan's soul. And without considering the multiplicity and complexity ofhe conditions any one of which taken separately may seem to be theause, he snatches at the first approximation to a cause that seems toim intelligible and says: "This is the cause!" In historical eventswhere the actions of men are the subject of observation) the firstnd most primitive approximation to present itself was the will of theods and, after that, the will of those who stood in the mostrominent position- the heroes of history. But we need onlyenetrate to the essence of any historic event- which lies in thectivity of the general mass of men who take part in it- to beonvinced that the will of the historic hero does not control thections of the mass but is itself continually controlled. It mayeem to be a matter of indifference whether we understand theeaning of historical events this way or that; yet there is the sameifference between a man who says that the people of the West moved onhe East because Napoleon wished it and a man who says that thisappened because it had to happen, as there is between those whoeclared that the earth was stationary and that the planets movedound it and those who admitted that they did not know what upheld thearth, but knew there were laws directing its movement and that of thether planets. There is, and can be, no cause of an historical eventxcept the one cause of all causes. But there are laws directingvents, and some of these laws are known to us while we areonscious of others we cannot comprehend. The discovery of theseaws is only possible when possible when we have quite abandoned thettempt to find the cause in the will of some one man, just as theiscovery of the laws of the motion of the planets was possible onlyhen men abandoned the conception of the fixity of the earth.
	The historians consider that, next to the battle of Borodino and theccupation of Moscow by the enemy and its destruction by fire, theost important episode of the war of 1812 was the movement of theussian army from the Ryazana to the Kaluga road and to the Tarutinoamp- the so-called flank march across the Krasnaya Pakhra River. Theyscribe the glory of that achievement of genius to different men andispute as to whom the honor is due. Even foreign historians,ncluding the French, acknowledge the genius of the Russian commandershen they speak of that flank march. But it is hard to understandhy military writers, and following them others, consider this flankarch to be the profound conception of some one man who saved Russiand destroyed Napoleon. In the first place it is hard to understandhere the profundity and genius of this movement lay, for not muchental effort was needed to see that the best position for an armyhen it is not being attacked is where there are most provisions;nd even a dull boy of thirteen could have guessed that the bestosition for an army after its retreat from Moscow in 1812 was onhe Kaluga road. So it is impossible to understand by what reasoninghe historians reach the conclusion that this maneuver was arofound one. And it is even more difficult to understand just whyhey think that this maneuver was calculated to save Russia andestroy the French; for this flank march, had it been preceded,ccompanied, or followed by other circumstances, might have proveduinous to the Russians and salutary for the French. If the positionf the Russian army really began to improve from the time of thatarch, it does not at all follow that the march was the cause of it.
	That flank march might not only have failed to give any advantage tohe Russian army, but might in other circumstances have led to itsestruction. What would have happened had Moscow not burned down? Ifurat had not lost sight of the Russians? If Napoleon had not remainednactive? If the Russian army at Krasnaya Pakhra had given battle asennigsen and Barclay advised? What would have happened had the Frenchttacked the Russians while they were marching beyond the Pakhra? Whatould have happened if on approaching Tarutino, Napoleon hadttacked the Russians with but a tenth of the energy he had shown whene attacked them at Smolensk? What would have happened had therench moved on Petersburg?... In any of these eventualities the flankarch that brought salvation might have proved disastrous.
	The third and most incomprehensible thing is that people studyingistory deliberately avoid seeing that this flank march cannot bettributed to any one man, that no one ever foresaw it, and that ineality, like the retreat from Fili, it did not suggest itself tonyone in its entirety, but resulted- moment by moment, step bytep, event by event- from an endless number of most diverseircumstances and was only seen in its entirety when it had beenccomplished and belonged to the past.
	At the council at Fili the prevailing thought in the minds of theussian commanders was the one naturally suggesting itself, namely, direct retreat by the Nizhni road. In proof of this there is theact that the majority of the council voted for such a retreat, andbove all there is the well-known conversation after the council,etween the commander in chief and Lanskoy, who was in charge of theommissariat department. Lanskoy informed the commander in chiefhat the army supplies were for the most part stored along the Okan the Tula and Ryazan provinces, and that if they retreated on Nizhnihe army would be separated from its supplies by the broad riverka, which cannot be crossed early in winter. This was the firstndication of the necessity of deviating from what had previouslyeemed the most natural course- a direct retreat on Nizhni-Novgorod.he army turned more to the south, along the Ryazan road and nearer tots supplies. Subsequently the in activity of the French (who evenost sight of the Russian army), concern for the safety of the arsenalt Tula, and especially the advantages of drawing nearer to itsupplies caused the army to turn still further south to the Tula road.aving crossed over, by a forced march, to the Tula road beyond theakhra, the Russian commanders intended to remain at Podolsk and hado thought of the Tarutino position; but innumerable circumstances andhe reappearance of French troops who had for a time lost touch withhe Russians, and projects of giving battle, and above all thebundance of provisions in Kaluga province, obliged our army to turntill more to the south and to cross from the Tula to the Kalugaoad and go to Tarutino, which was between the roads along which thoseupplies lay. Just as it is impossible to say when it was decided tobandon Moscow, so it is impossible to say precisely when, or by whom,t was decided to move to Tarutino. Only when the army had gothere, as the result of innumerable and varying forces, did peopleegin to assure themselves that they had desired this movement andong ago foreseen its result.BK13|CH2
	CHAPTER II
	The famous flank movement merely consisted in this: after thedvance of the French had ceased, the Russian army, which had beenontinually retreating straight back from the invaders, deviatedrom that direct course and, not finding itself pursued, was naturallyrawn toward the district where supplies were abundant.
	If instead of imagining to ourselves commanders of genius leadinghe Russian army, we picture that army without any leaders, it couldot have done anything but make a return movement toward Moscow,escribing an arc in the direction where most provisions were to beound and where the country was richest.
	That movement from the Nizhni to the Ryazan, Tula, and Kalugaoads was so natural that even the Russian marauders moved in thatirection, and demands were sent from Petersburg for Kutuzov to takeis army that way. 	CHAPTER III

	CHAPTER VI

No battle- Tarutino,orodino, or Austerlitz- takes place as those who planned itnticipated. That is an essential condition.
	A countless number of free forces (for nowhere is man freer thanuring a battle, where it is a question of life and death) influencehe course taken by the fight, and that course never can be known indvance and never coincides with the direction of any one force.
	If many simultaneously and variously directed forces act on aiven body, the direction of its motion cannot coincide with any onef those forces, but will always be a mean- what in mechanics isepresented by the diagonal of a parallelogram of forces.
	If in the descriptions given by historians, especially Frenchnes, we find their wars and battles carried out in accordance withreviously formed plans, the only conclusion to be drawn is that thoseescriptions are false.

It would be difficult and evenmpossible to imagine any result more opportune than the actualutcome of this battle. 	CHAPTER VIII
	Napoleon enters Moscow after the brilliant victory de la Moskowa;here can be no doubt about the victory for the battlefield remains inhe hands of the French. The Russians retreat and abandon theirncient capital. Moscow, abounding in provisions, arms, munitions, andncalculable wealth, is in Napoleon's hands. The Russian army, onlyalf the strength of the French, does not make a single attempt tottack for a whole month. Napoleon's position is most brilliant. Hean either fall on the Russian army with double its strength andestroy it; negotiate an advantageous peace, or in case of a refusalake a menacing move on Petersburg, or even, in the case of a reverse,eturn to Smolensk or Vilna; or remain in Moscow; in short, no specialenius would seem to be required to retain the brilliant positionhe French held at that time. For that, only very simple and easyteps were necessary: not to allow the troops to loot, to prepareinter clothing- of which there was sufficient in Moscow for the wholermy- and methodically to collect the provisions, of whichaccording to the French historians) there were enough in Moscow toupply the whole army for six months. Yet Napoleon, that greatest ofll geniuses, who the historians declare had control of the army, tookone of these steps.
	He not merely did nothing of the kind, but on the contrary he usedis power to select the most foolish and ruinous of all the coursespen to him. Of all that Napoleon might have done: wintering inoscow, advancing on Petersburg or on Nizhni-Novgorod, or retiringy a more northerly or more southerly route (say by the road Kutuzovfterwards took), nothing more stupid or disastrous can be imaginedhan what he actually did. He remained in Moscow till October, lettinghe troops plunder the city; then, hesitating whether to leave aarrison behind him, he quitted Moscow, approached Kutuzov withoutoining battle, turned to the right and reached Malo-Yaroslavets,gain without attempting to break through and take the road Kutuzovook, but retiring instead to Mozhaysk along the devastated Smolenskoad. Nothing more stupid than that could have been devised, or moreisastrous for the army, as the sequel showed. Had Napoleon's aim beeno destroy his army, the most skillful strategist could hardly haveevised any series of actions that would so completely haveccomplished that purpose, independently of anything the Russianrmy might do.
	Napoleon, the man of genius, did this! But to say that heestroyed his army because he wished to, or because he was verytupid, would be as unjust as to say that he had brought his troops tooscow because he wished to and because he was very clever and aenius.
	In both cases his personal activity, having no more force than theersonal activity of any soldier, merely coincided with the lawshat guided the event.
	The historians quite falsely represent Napoleon's faculties asaving weakened in Moscow, and do so only because the results didot justify his actions. He employed all his ability and strength too the best he could for himself and his army, as he had donereviously and as he did subsequently in 1813. 	CHAPTER XI

	CHAPTER XII

	CHAPTER XIII

	CHAPTER XV
	In the early days of October another envoy came to Kutuzov with aetter from Napoleon proposing peace and falsely dated from Moscow,hough Napoleon was already not far from Kutuzov on the old Kalugaoad. 	It is natural for a man who does not understand the workings of aachine to imagine that a shaving that has fallen into it by chancend is interfering with its action and tossing about in it is its mostmportant part. 	CHAPTER XVII

	CHAPTER XVIII
	From the time he received this news to the end of the campaign allutuzov's activity was directed toward restraining his troops, byuthority, by guile, and by entreaty, from useless attacks, maneuvers,r encounters with the perishing enemy. 	CHAPTER XIX
	A man in motion always devises an aim for that motion. To be able too a thousand miles he must imagine that something good awaits himt the end of those thousand miles. One must have the prospect of aromised land to have the strength to move.
	The promised land for the French during their advance had beenoscow, during their retreat it was their native land. 	For the French retreating along the old Smolensk road, the finaloal- their native land- was too remote, and their immediate goalas Smolensk, toward which all their desires and hopes, enormouslyntensified in the mass, urged them on. 	CHAPTER I
	The Battle of Borodino, with the occupation of Moscow thatollowed it and the flight of the French without further conflicts, isne of the most instructive phenomena in history.
	All historians agree that the external activity of states andations in their conflicts with one another is expressed in wars,nd that as a direct result of greater or less success in war theolitical strength of states and nations increases or decreases.
	Strange as may be the historical account of how some king ormperor, having quarreled with another, collects an army, fights hisnemy's army, gains a victory by killing three, five, or tenhousand men, and subjugates a kingdom and an entire nation of severalillions, all the facts of history (as far as we know it) confirmhe truth of the statement that the greater or lesser success of onermy against another is the cause, or at least an essentialndication, of an increase or decrease in the strength of theation- even though it is unintelligible why the defeat of an army- hundredth part of a nation- should oblige that whole nation toubmit. An army gains a victory, and at once the rights of theonquering nation have increased to the detriment of the defeated.n army has suffered defeat, and at once a people loses its rightsn proportion to the severity of the reverse, and if its armyuffers a complete defeat the nation is quite subjugated.
	So according to history it has been found from the most ancientimes, and so it is to our own day. All Napoleon's wars serve toonfirm this rule. In proportion to the defeat of the Austrian armyustria loses its rights, and the rights and the strength of Francencrease. The victories of the French at Jena and Auerstadt destroyhe independent existence of Prussia.
	But then, in 1812, the French gain a victory near Moscow. Moscows taken and after that, with no further battles, it is not Russiahat ceases to exist, but the French army of six hundred thousand, andhen Napoleonic France itself. To strain the facts to fit the rules ofistory: to say that the field of battle at Borodino remained in theands of the Russians, or that after Moscow there were other battleshat destroyed Napoleon's army, is impossible.
	After the French victory at Borodino there was no general engagementor any that were at all serious, yet the French army ceased to exist.hat does this mean? If it were an example taken from the history ofhina, we might say that it was not an historic phenomenon (which ishe historians' usual expedient when anything does not fit theirtandards); if the matter concerned some brief conflict in whichnly a small number of troops took part, we might treat it as anxception; but this event occurred before our fathers' eyes, and forhem it was a question of the life or death of their fatherland, andt happened in the greatest of all known wars.
	The period of the campaign of 1812 from the battle of Borodino tohe expulsion of the French proved that the winning of a battle doesot produce a conquest and is not even an invariable indication ofonquest; it proved that the force which decides the fate of peoplesies not in the conquerors, nor even in armies and battles, but inomething else.
	The French historians, describing the condition of the French armyefore it left Moscow, affirm that all was in order in the Grand Army,xcept the cavalry, the artillery, and the transport- there was noorage for the horses or the cattle. That was a misfortune no oneould remedy, for the peasants of the district burned their hay ratherhan let the French have it.

	Let us imagine two men who have come out to fight a duel withapiers according to all the rules of the art of fencing. 	The fencer who demanded a contest according to the rules ofencing was the French army; his opponent who threw away the rapiernd snatched up the cudgel was the Russian people; those who try toxplain the matter according to the rules of fencing are theistorians who have described the event.
	After the burning of Smolensk a war began which did not follow anyrevious traditions of war. 	CHAPTER II
	One of the most obvious and advantageous departures from theo-called laws of war is the action of scattered groups against menressed together in a mass. Such action always occurs in wars thatake on a national character. In such actions, instead of two crowdspposing each other, the men disperse, attack singly, run away whenttacked by stronger forces, but again attack when opportunity offers.his was done by the guerrillas in Spain, by the mountain tribes inhe Caucasus, and by the Russians in 1812.
	People have called this kind of war "guerrilla warfare" and assumehat by so calling it they have explained its meaning. But such aar does not fit in under any rule and is directly opposed to aell-known rule of tactics which is accepted as infallible. Thatule says that an attacker should concentrate his forces in order toe stronger than his opponent at the moment of conflict.
	Guerrilla war (always successful, as history shows) directlynfringes that rule.
	This contradiction arises from the fact that military sciencessumes the strength of an army to be identical with its numbers.ilitary science says that the more troops the greater the strength.es gros bataillons ont toujours raison.*
	*Large battalions are always victorious.
	For military science to say this is like defining momentum inechanics by reference to the mass only: stating that momenta arequal or unequal to each other simply because the masses involvedre equal or unequal.
	Momentum (quantity of motion) is the product of mass and velocity.
	In military affairs the strength of an army is the product of itsass and some unknown x.
	Military science, seeing in history innumerable instances of theact that the size of any army does not coincide with its strength andhat small detachments defeat larger ones, obscurely admits thexistence of this unknown factor and tries to discover it- now in aeometric formation, now in the equipment employed, now, and mostsually, in the genius of the commanders. But the assignment ofhese various meanings to the factor does not yield results whichccord with the historic facts.
	Yet it is only necessary to abandon the false view (adopted toratify the "heroes") of the efficacy of the directions issued inartime by commanders, in order to find this unknown quantity.
	That unknown quantity is the spirit of the army, that is to say, thereater or lesser readiness to fight and face danger felt by all theen composing an army, quite independently of whether they are, or areot, fighting under the command of a genius, in two- or three-lineormation, with cudgels or with rifles that repeat thirty times ainute. Men who want to fight will always put themselves in the mostdvantageous conditions for fighting.
	The spirit of an army is the factor which multiplied by the massives the resulting force. To define and express the significance ofhis unknown factor- the spirit of an army- is a problem for science.
	This problem is only solvable if we cease arbitrarily toubstitute for the unknown x itself the conditions under which thatorce becomes apparent- such as the commands of the general, thequipment employed, and so on- mistaking these for the realignificance of the factor, and if we recognize this unknownuantity in its entirety as being the greater or lesser desire toight and to face danger. Only then, expressing known historic factsy equations and comparing the relative significance of this factor,an we hope to define the unknown.
	Ten men, battalions, or divisions, fighting fifteen men, battalions,r divisions, conquer- that is, kill or take captive- all thethers, while themselves losing four, so that on the one side four andn the other fifteen were lost. Consequently the four were equal tohe fifteen, and therefore 4x = 15y. Consequently x/y = 15/4. Thisquation does not give us the value of the unknown factor but gives us ratio between two unknowns. And by bringing variously selectedistoric units (battles, campaigns, periods of war) into suchquations, a series of numbers could be obtained in which certain lawshould exist and might be discovered.
	The tactical rule that an army should act in masses whenttacking, and in smaller groups in retreat, unconsciously confirmshe truth that the strength of an army depends on its spirit. Toead men forward under fire more discipline (obtainable only byovement in masses) is needed than is needed to resist attacks. Buthis rule which leaves out of account the spirit of the armyontinually proves incorrect and is in particularly strikingontrast to the facts when some strong rise or fall in the spirit ofhe troops occurs, as in all national wars.
	The French, retreating in 1812- though according to tactics theyhould have separated into detachments to defend themselves-ongregated into a mass because the spirit of the army had so fallenhat only the mass held the army together. The Russians, on theontrary, ought according to tactics to have attacked in mass, butn fact they split up into small units, because their spirit had soisen that separate individuals, without orders, dealt blows at therench without needing any compulsion to induce them to exposehemselves to hardships and dangers.BK14|CH3
	CHAPTER III
	The so-called partisan war began with the entry of the French intomolensk.

	CHAPTER XV
	The stores, the prisoners, and the marshal's baggage train stoppedt the village of Shamshevo. The men crowded together round theampfires. 	CHAPTER XVI
	After the twenty-eighth of October when the frosts began, the flightf the French assumed a still more tragic character, with menreezing, or roasting themselves to death at the campfires, whilearriages with people dressed in furs continued to drive past,arrying away the property that had been stolen by the Emperor, kings,nd dukes; but the process of the flight and disintegration of therench army went on essentially as before.

	CHAPTER XVII
	The movements of the Russian and French armies during the campaignrom Moscow back to the Niemen were like those in a game of Russianlindman's bluff, in which two players are blindfolded and one of themccasionally rings a little bell to inform the catcher of hishereabouts. 	At first while they were still moving along the Kaluga road,apoleon's armies made their presence known, but later when theyeached the Smolensk road they ran holding the clapper of their bellight- and often thinking they were escaping ran right into theussians.
	Owing to the rapidity of the French flight and the Russian pursuitnd the consequent exhaustion of the horses, the chief means ofpproximately ascertaining the enemy's position- by cavalrycouting- was not available. 	One army fled and the other pursued. 	CHAPTER XVIII
	This campaign consisted in a flight of the French during whichhey did all they could to destroy themselves. From the time theyurned onto the Kaluga road to the day their leader fled from thermy, none of the movements of the crowd had any sense. So one mightave thought that regarding this period of the campaign theistorians, who attributed the actions of the mass to the will ofne man, would have found it impossible to make the story of theetreat fit their theory. But no! Mountains of books have been writteny the historians about this campaign, and everywhere are describedapoleon's arrangements, the maneuvers, and his profound plans whichuided the army, as well as the military genius shown by his marshals.
	The retreat from Malo-Yaroslavets when he had a free road into aell-supplied district and the parallel road was open to him alonghich Kutuzov afterwards pursued him- this unnecessary retreat along aevastated road- is explained to us as being due to profoundonsiderations. Similarly profound considerations are given for hisetreat from Smolensk to Orsha. 	"J'ai assez fait l'empereur; il est temps de faire le general,"* butevertheless immediately ran away again, abandoning to its fate thecattered fragments of the army he left behind.
	*"I have acted the Emperor long enough; it is time to act theeneral."
	Then we are told of the greatness of soul of the marshals,specially of Ney- a greatness of soul consisting in this: that heade his way by night around through the forest and across the Dniepernd escaped to Orsha, abandoning standards, artillery, and nine tenthsf his men.
	And lastly, the final departure of the great Emperor from his heroicrmy is presented to us by the historians as something great andharacteristic of genius. Even that final running away, described inrdinary language as the lowest depth of baseness which every child isaught to be ashamed of- even that act finds justification in theistorians' language.
	When it is impossible to stretch the very elastic threads ofistorical ratiocination any farther, when actions are clearlyontrary to all that humanity calls right or even just, the historiansroduce a saving conception of "greatness." "Greatness," it seems,xcludes the standards of right and wrong. For the "great" man nothings wrong, there is no atrocity for which a "great" man can be blamed.
	"C'est grand!"* say the historians, and there no longer existsither good or evil but only "grand" and "not grand." Grand is good,ot grand is bad. Grand is the characteristic, in their conception, ofome special animals called "heroes." And Napoleon, escaping home in aarm fur coat and leaving to perish those who were not merely hisomrades but were (in his opinion) men he had brought there, feels que'est grand,*[2] and his soul is tranquil.
	*"It is great."
	*[2] That it is great.
	"Du sublime (he saw something sublime in himself) au ridicule il n'y qu'un pas,"* said he. And the whole world for fifty years has beenepeating: "Sublime! Grand! Napoleon le Grand!" Du sublime au ridiculel n'y a qu'un pas.
	*"From the sublime to the ridiculous is but a step."
	And it occurs to no one that to admit a greatness notommensurable with the standard of right and wrong is merely todmit one's own nothingness and immeasurable meanness.
	For us with the standard of good and evil given us by Christ, nouman actions are incommensurable. And there is no greatness whereimplicity, goodness, and truth are absent.BK14|CH19
	CHAPTER XIX
	What Russian, reading the account of the last part of the campaignf 1812, has not experienced an uncomfortable feeling of regret,issatisfaction, and perplexity? Who has not asked himself how it ishat the French were not all captured or destroyed when our threermies surrounded them in superior numbers, when the disorderedrench, hungry and freezing, surrendered in crowds, and when (as theistorians relate) the aim of the Russians was to stop the French,o cut them off, and capture them all?
	How was it that the Russian army, which when numerically weaker thanhe French had given battle at Borodino, did not achieve its purposehen it had surrounded the French on three sides and when its aimas to capture them? Can the French be so enormously superior to ushat when we had surrounded them with superior forces we could noteat them? How could that happen?
	History (or what is called by that name) replying to these questionsays that this occurred because Kutuzov and Tormasov and Chichagov,nd this man and that man, did not execute such and such maneuvers...
	But why did they not execute those maneuvers? And why if they wereuilty of not carrying out a prearranged plan were they not triednd punished? But even if we admitted that Kutuzov, Chichagov, andthers were the cause of the Russian failures, it is stillncomprehensible why, the position of the Russian army being what itas at Krasnoe and at the Berezina (in both cases we had superiororces), the French army with its marshals, kings, and Emperor was notaptured, if that was what the Russians aimed at.
	The explanation of this strange fact given by Russian militaryistorians (to the effect that Kutuzov hindered an attack) isnfounded, for we know that he could not restrain the troops fromttacking at Vyazma and Tarutino.
	Why was the Russian army- which with inferior forces had withstoodhe enemy in full strength at Borodino- defeated at Krasnoe and theerezina by the disorganized crowds of the French when it wasumerically superior?
	If the aim of the Russians consisted in cutting off and capturingapoleon and his marshals- and that aim was not merely frustratedut all attempts to attain it were most shamefully baffled- thenhis last period of the campaign is quite rightly considered by therench to be a series of victories, and quite wrongly consideredictorious by Russian historians.
	The Russian military historians in so far as they submit to claimsf logic must admit that conclusion, and in spite of their lyricalhapsodies about valor, devotion, and so forth, must reluctantly admithat the French retreat from Moscow was a series of victories forapoleon and defeats for Kutuzov.
	But putting national vanity entirely aside one feels that such aonclusion involves a contradiction, since the series of Frenchictories brought the French complete destruction, while the series ofussian defeats led to the total destruction of their enemy and theiberation of their country.
	The source of this contradiction lies in the fact that theistorians studying the events from the letters of the sovereignsnd the generals, from memoirs, reports, projects, and so forth,ave attributed to this last period of the war of 1812 an aim thatever existed, namely that of cutting off and capturing Napoleonith his marshals and his army.
	There never was or could have been such an aim, for it would haveeen senseless and its attainment quite impossible.
	It would have been senseless, first because Napoleon'sisorganized army was flying from Russia with all possible speed, thats to say, was doing just what every Russian desired. So what washe use of performing various operations on the French who wereunning away as fast as they possibly could?
	Secondly, it would have been senseless to block the passage of menhose whole energy was directed to flight.
	Thirdly, it would have been senseless to sacrifice one's ownroops in order to destroy the French army, which without externalnterference was destroying itself at such a rate that, though itsath was not blocked, it could not carry across the frontier more thant actually did in December, namely a hundredth part of the originalrmy.
	Fourthly, it would have been senseless to wish to take captive themperor, kings, and dukes- whose capture would have been in theighest degree embarrassing for the Russians, as the most adroitiplomatists of the time (Joseph de Maistre and others) recognized.till more senseless would have been the wish to capture army corps ofhe French, when our own army had melted away to half beforeeaching Krasnoe and a whole division would have been needed to convoyhe corps of prisoners, and when our men were not always gettingull rations and the prisoners already taken were perishing of hunger.
	All the profound plans about cutting off and capturing Napoleonnd his army were like the plan of a market gardener who, when drivingut of his garden a cow that had trampled down the beds he hadlanted, should run to the gate and hit the cow on the head. Thenly thing to be said in excuse of that gardener would be that heas very angry. But not even that could be said for those who drewp this project, for it was not they who had suffered from therampled beds.
	But besides the fact that cutting off Napoleon with his army wouldave been senseless, it was impossible.
	It was impossible first because- as experience shows that ahree-mile movement of columns on a battlefield never coincides withhe plans- the probability of Chichagov, Kutuzov, and Wittgensteinffecting a junction on time at an appointed place was so remote as toe tantamount to impossibility, as in fact thought Kutuzov, who whene received the plan remarked that diversions planned over greatistances do not yield the desired results.
	Secondly it was impossible, because to paralyze the momentum withhich Napoleon's army was retiring, incomparably greater forces thanhe Russians possessed would have been required.
	Thirdly it was impossible, because the military term "to cut off"as no meaning. One can cut off a slice of bread, but not an army.o cut off an army- to bar its road- is quite impossible, for there islways plenty of room to avoid capture and there is the night whenothing can be seen, as the military scientists might convincehemselves by the example of Krasnoe and of the Berezina. It is onlyossible to capture prisoners if they agree to be captured, just as its only possible to catch a swallow if it settles on one's hand. Menan only be taken prisoners if they surrender according to the rulesf strategy and tactics, as the Germans did. But the French troopsuite rightly did not consider that this suited them, since death byunger and cold awaited them in flight or captivity alike.
	Fourthly and chiefly it was impossible, because never since theorld began has a war been fought under such conditions as thosehat obtained in 1812, and the Russian army in its pursuit of therench strained its strength to the utmost and could not have doneore without destroying itself.
	During the movement of the Russian army from Tarutino to Krasnoet lost fifty thousand sick or stragglers, that is a number equal tohe population of a large provincial town. Half the men fell out ofhe army without a battle.
	And it is of this period of the campaign- when the army lacked bootsnd sheepskin coats, was short of provisions and without vodka, andas camping out at night for months in the snow with fifteen degreesf frost, when there were only seven or eight hours of daylight andhe rest was night in which the influence of discipline cannot beaintained, when men were taken into that region of death whereiscipline fails, not for a few hours only as in a battle, but foronths, where they were every moment fighting death from hunger andold, when half the army perished in a single month- it is of thiseriod of the campaign that the historians tell us how Miloradovichhould have made a flank march to such and such a place, Tormasov tonother place, and Chichagov should have crossed (more thannee-deep in snow) to somewhere else, and how so-and-so "routed" andcut off" the French and so on and so on.
	The Russians, half of whom died, did all that could and shouldave been done to attain an end worthy of the nation, and they are noto blame because other Russians, sitting in warm rooms, proposedhat they should do what was impossible.
	All that strange contradiction now difficult to understand betweenhe facts and the historical accounts only arises because theistorians dealing with the matter have written the history of theeautiful words and sentiments of various generals, and not theistory of the events.
	To them the words of Miloradovich seem very interesting, and so doheir surmises and the rewards this or that general received; buthe question of those fifty thousand men who were left in hospitalsnd in graves does not even interest them, for it does not come withinhe range of their investigation.
	Yet one need only discard the study of the reports and general plansnd consider the movement of those hundreds of thousands of men whoook a direct part in the events, and all the questions that seemednsoluble easily and simply receive an immediate and certain solution.
	The aim of cutting off Napoleon and his army never existed except inhe imaginations of a dozen people. It could not exist because itas senseless and unattainable.
	The people had a single aim: to free their land from invasion.hat aim was attained in the first place of itself, as the Frenchan away, and so it was only necessary not to stop their flight.econdly it was attained by the guerrilla warfare which was destroyinghe French, and thirdly by the fact that a large Russian army wasollowing the French, ready to use its strength in case their movementtopped.
	The Russian army had to act like a whip to a running animal. And thexperienced driver knew it was better to hold the whip raised as aenace than to strike the running animal on the head.BK15	                          BOOK FIFTEEN: 1812 - 13BK15|CH1
	CHAPTER I
	When seeing a dying animal a man feels a sense of horror:ubstance similar to his own is perishing before his eyes. But when its a beloved and intimate human being that is dying, besides thisorror at the extinction of life there is a severance, a spiritualound, which like a physical wound is sometimes fatal and sometimeseals, but always aches and shrinks at any external irritating touch.
	After Prince Andrew's death Natasha and Princess Mary alike felthis. Drooping in spirit and closing their eyes before the menacingloud of death that overhung them, they dared not look life in theace. They carefully guarded their open wounds from any rough andainful contact. Everything: a carriage passing rapidly in the street, summons to dinner, the maid's inquiry what dress to prepare, ororse still any word of insincere or feeble sympathy, seemed annsult, painfully irritated the wound, interrupting that necessaryuiet in which they both tried to listen to the stern and dreadfulhoir that still resounded in their imagination, and hindered theirazing into those mysterious limitless vistas that for an instantad opened out before them.
	Only when alone together were they free from such outrage andain. They spoke little even to one another, and when they did itas of very unimportant matters.
	Both avoided any allusion to the future. To admit the possibility of future seemed to them to insult his memory. Still more carefully didhey avoid anything relating to him who was dead. It seemed to themhat what they had lived through and experienced could not bexpressed in words, and that any reference to the details of hisife infringed the majesty and sacredness of the mystery that had beenccomplished before their eyes.
	Continued abstention from speech, and constant avoidance ofverything that might lead up to the subject- this halting on allides at the boundary of what they might not mention- brought beforeheir minds with still greater purity and clearness what they wereoth feeling.
	But pure and complete sorrow is as impossible as pure and completeoy. Princess Mary, in her position as absolute and independentrbiter of her own fate and guardian and instructor of her nephew, washe first to be called back to life from that realm of sorrow in whichhe had dwelt for the first fortnight. She received letters from herelations to which she had to reply; the room in which little Nicholasad been put was damp and he began to cough; Alpatych came toaroslavl with reports on the state of their affairs and with advicend suggestions that they should return to Moscow to the house onhe Vozdvizhenka Street, which had remained uninjured and needednly slight repairs. Life did not stand still and it was necessaryo live. Hard as it was for Princess Mary to emerge from the realmf secluded contemplation in which she had lived till then, andorry and almost ashamed as she felt to leave Natasha alone, yet theares of life demanded her attention and she involuntarily yieldedo them. She went through the accounts with Alpatych, conferred withessalles about her nephew, and gave orders and made preparationsor the journey to Moscow.
	Natasha remained alone and, from the time Princess Mary began makingreparations for departure, held aloof from her too.
	Princess Mary asked the countess to let Natasha go with her tooscow, and both parents gladly accepted this offer, for they sawheir daughter losing strength every day and thought that a changef scene and the advice of Moscow doctors would be good for her.
	"I am not going anywhere," Natasha replied when this was proposed toer. "Do please just leave me alone!" And she ran out of the room,ith difficulty refraining from tears of vexation and irritationather than of sorrow.
	After she felt herself deserted by Princes Mary and alone in herrief, Natasha spent most of the time in her room by herself,itting huddled up feet and all in the corner of the sofa, tearing andwisting something with her slender nervous fingers and gazingntently and fixedly at whatever her eyes chanced to fall on. Thisolitude exhausted and tormented her but she was in absolute need oft. As soon as anyone entered she got up quickly, changed her positionnd expression, and picked up a book or some sewing, evidently waitingmpatiently for the intruder to go.
	She felt all the time as if she might at any moment penetrate thatn which- with a terrible questioning too great for her strength-er spiritual gaze was fixed.
	One day toward the end of December Natasha, pale and thin, dressedn a black woolen gown, her plaited hair negligently twisted into anot, was crouched feet and all in the corner of her sofa, nervouslyrumpling and smoothing out the end of her sash while she looked at corner of the door.
	She was gazing in the direction in which he had gone- to the otheride of life. And that other side of life, of which she had neverefore thought and which had formerly seemed to her so far away andmprobable, was now nearer and more akin and more comprehensiblehan this side of life, where everything was either emptiness andesolation or suffering and indignity.

	CHAPTER IV
	After the encounter at Vyazma, where Kutuzov had been unable to holdack his troops in their anxiety to overwhelm and cut off the enemynd so on, the farther movement of the fleeing French, and of theussians who pursued them, continued as far as Krasnoe without aattle. 	The rapidity of the Russian pursuit was just as destructive to ourrmy as the flight of the French was to theirs. 	CHAPTER V
	In 1812 and 1813 Kutuzov was openly accused of blundering. Themperor was dissatisfied with him. 	Such is the fate not of great men (grands hommes) whom the Russianind does not acknowledge, but of those rare and always solitaryndividuals who, discerning the will of Providence, submit theirersonal will to it. The hatred and contempt of the crowd punishuch men for discerning the higher laws.

	CHAPTER VI

	CHAPTER X
	The French army melted away at the uniform rate of a mathematicalrogression; and that crossing of the Berezina about which so much haseen written was only one intermediate stage in its destruction, andot at all the decisive episode of the campaign. If so much has beennd still is written about the Berezina, on the French side this isnly because at the broken bridge across that river the calamitiesheir army had been previously enduring were suddenly concentratedt one moment into a tragic spectacle that remained in every memory,nd on the Russian side merely because in Petersburg- far from theeat of war- a plan (again one of Pfuel's) had been devised to catchapoleon in a strategic trap at the Berezina River. 	The sole importance of the crossing of the Berezina lies in the facthat it plainly and indubitably proved the fallacy of all the plansor cutting off the enemy's retreat and the soundness of the onlyossible line of action- the one Kutuzov and the general mass of thermy demanded- namely, simply to follow the enemy up. The French crowdled at a continually increasing speed and all its energy was directedo reaching its goal. It fled like a wounded animal and it wasmpossible to block its path. 	That impulse was reasonable. The condition of fugitives and ofursuers was equally bad. 	CHAPTER XI
	Next day the field marshal gave a dinner and ball which themperor honored by his presence. 	CHAPTER XIV

	CHAPTER I
	Seven years had passed. The storm-tossed sea of European history hadubsided within its shores and seemed to have become calm. But theysterious forces that move humanity (mysterious because the laws ofheir motion are unknown to us) continued to operate.
	Though the surface of the sea of history seemed motionless, theovement of humanity went on as unceasingly as the flow of time.arious groups of people formed and dissolved, the coming formationnd dissolution of kingdoms and displacement of peoples was inourse of preparation.
	The sea of history was not driven spasmodically from shore tohore as previously. It was seething in its depths. Historic figuresere not borne by the waves from one shore to another as before.hey now seemed to rotate on one spot. The historical figures at theead of armies, who formerly reflected the movement of the masses byrdering wars, campaigns, and battles, now reflected the restlessovement by political and diplomatic combinations, laws, and treaties.
	The historians call this activity of the historical figures "theeaction."
	In dealing with this period they sternly condemn the historicalersonages who, in their opinion, caused what they describe as theeaction. All the well-known people of that period, from Alexander andapoleon to Madame de Stael, Photius, Schelling, Fichte,hateaubriand, and the rest, pass before their stern judgment seat andre acquitted or condemned according to whether they conduced torogress or to reaction.
	According to their accounts a reaction took place at that time inussia also, and the chief culprit was Alexander I, the same man whoccording to them was the chief cause of the liberal movement at theommencement of his reign, being the savior of Russia.
	There is no one in Russian literature now, from schoolboy essayisto learned historian, who does not throw his little stone at Alexanderor things he did wrong at this period of his reign.
	"He ought to have acted in this way and in that way. In this case heid well and in that case badly. He behaved admirably at the beginningf his reign and during 1812, but acted badly by giving a constitutiono Poland, forming the Holy Alliance, entrusting power to Arakcheev,avoring Golitsyn and mysticism, and afterwards Shishkov andhotius. He also acted badly by concerning himself with the activermy and disbanding the Semenov regiment."
	It would take a dozen pages to enumerate all the reproaches theistorians address to him, based on their knowledge of what is goodor humanity.
	What do these reproaches mean?
	Do not the very actions for which the historians praise Alexander (the liberal attempts at the beginning of his reign, his struggleith Napoleon, the firmness he displayed in 1812 and the campaign of813) flow from the same sources- the circumstances of his birth,ducation, and life- that made his personality what it was and fromhich the actions for which they blame him (the Holy Alliance, theestoration of Poland, and the reaction of 1820 and later) alsolowed?
	In what does the substance of those reproaches lie?
	It lies in the fact that an historic character like Alexander I,tanding on the highest possible pinnacle of human power with thelinding light of history focused upon him; a character exposed tohose strongest of all influences: the intrigues, flattery, andelf-deception inseparable from power; a character who at every momentf his life felt a responsibility for all that was happening inurope; and not a fictitious but a live character who like every manad his personal habits, passions, and impulses toward goodness,eauty, and truth- that this character- though not lacking in virtuethe historians do not accuse him of that)- had not the sameonception of the welfare of humanity fifty years ago as a present-dayrofessor who from his youth upwards has been occupied withearning: that is, with books and lectures and with taking notesrom them.
	But even if we assume that fifty years ago Alexander I wasistaken in his view of what was good for the people, we mustnevitably assume that the historian who judges Alexander will alsofter the lapse of some time turn out to be mistaken in his view ofhat is good for humanity. This assumption is all the more natural andnevitable because, watching the movement of history, we see thatvery year and with each new writer, opinion as to what is good forankind changes; so that what once seemed good, ten years latereems bad, and vice versa. And what is more, we find at one and theame time quite contradictory views as to what is bad and what is goodn history: some people regard giving a constitution to Poland andorming the Holy Alliance as praiseworthy in Alexander, while othersegard it as blameworthy.
	The activity of Alexander or of Napoleon cannot be called usefulr harmful, for it is impossible to say for what it was useful orarmful. If that activity displeases somebody, this is only because itoes not agree with his limited understanding of what is good. Whetherhe preservation of my father's house in Moscow, or the glory of theussian arms, or the prosperity of the Petersburg and otherniversities, or the freedom of Poland or the greatness of Russia,r the balance of power in Europe, or a certain kind of Europeanulture called "progress" appear to me to be good or bad, I must admithat besides these things the action of every historic character hasther more general purposes inaccessible to me.
	But let us assume that what is called science can harmonize allontradictions and possesses an unchanging standard of good and bad byhich to try historic characters and events; let us say that Alexanderould have done everything differently; let us say that withuidance from those who blame him and who profess to know the ultimateim of the movement of humanity, he might have arranged mattersccording to the program his present accusers would have given him- ofationality, freedom, equality, and progress (these, I think, coverhe ground). What would thenave become of the activity of all those who opposed the tendency thathen prevailed in the government- an activity that in the opinion ofhe historians was good and beneficent? Their activity would notave existed: there would have been no life, there would have beenothing.
	If we admit that human life can be ruled by reason, theossibility of life is destroyed.EP1|CH2
	CHAPTER II
	If we assume as the historians do that great men lead humanity tohe attainment of certain ends- the greatness of Russia or ofrance, the balance of power in Europe, the diffusion of the ideasf the Revolution general progress or anything else- then it ismpossible to explain the facts of history without introducing theonceptions of chance and genius.
	If the aim of the European wars at the beginning of the nineteenthentury had been the aggrandizement of Russia, that aim might haveeen accomplished without all the preceding wars and without thenvasion. If the aim wag the aggrandizement of France, that might haveeen attained without the Revolution and without the Empire. If theim was the dissemination of ideas, the printing press could haveccomplished that much better than warfare. If the aim was therogress of civilization, it is easy to see that there are otherays of diffusing civilization more expedient than by theestruction of wealth and of human lives.
	Why did it happen in this and not in some other way?
	Because it happened so! "Chance created the situation; geniustilized it," says history.
	But what is chance? What is genius?
	The words chance and genius do not denote any really existinghing and therefore cannot be defined. Those words only denote aertain stage of understanding of phenomena. I do not know why aertain event occurs; I think that I cannot know it; so I do not tryo know it and I talk about chance. I see a force producing effectseyond the scope of ordinary human agencies; I do not understand whyhis occurs and I talk of genius.
	To a herd of rams, the ram the herdsman drives each evening into apecial enclosure to feed and that becomes twice as fat as thethers must seem to be a genius. And it must appear an astonishingonjunction of genius with a whole series of extraordinary chanceshat this ram, who instead of getting into the general fold everyvening goes into a special enclosure where there are oats- thathis very ram, swelling with fat, is killed for meat.
	But the rams need only cease to suppose that all that happens tohem happens solely for the attainment of their sheepish aims; theyeed only admit that what happens to them may also have purposeseyond their ken, and they will at once perceive a unity and coherencen what happened to the ram that was fattened. Even if they do notnow for what purpose they are fattened, they will at least knowhat all that happened to the ram did not happen accidentally, andill no longer need the conceptions of chance or genius.
	Only by renouncing our claim to discern a purpose immediatelyntelligible to us, and admitting the ultimate purpose to be beyondur ken, may we discern the sequence of experiences in the lives ofistoric characters and perceive the cause of the effect theyroduce (incommensurable with ordinary human capabilities), and thenhe words chance and genius become superfluous.
	We need only confess that we do not know the purpose of the Europeanonvulsions and that we know only the facts- that is, the murders,irst in France, then in Italy, in Africa, in Prussia, in Austria,n Spain, and in Russia- and that the movements from the west to theast and from the east to the west form the essence and purpose ofhese events, and not only shall we have no need to see exceptionalbility and genius in Napoleon and Alexander, but we shall be unableo consider them to be anything but like other men, and we shall note obliged to have recourse to chance for an explanation of thosemall events which made these people what they were, but it will belear that all those small events were inevitable.
	By discarding a claim to knowledge of the ultimate purpose, we shalllearly perceive that just as one cannot imagine a blossom or seed forny single plant better suited to it than those it produces, so its impossible to imagine any two people more completely adapted downo the smallest detail for the purpose they had to fulfill, thanapoleon and Alexander with all their antecedents.EP1|CH3
	CHAPTER III
	The fundamental and essential significance of the European events ofhe beginning of the nineteenth century lies in the movement of theass of the European peoples from west to east and afterwards fromast to west. 	CHAPTER IV
	The flood of nations begins to subside into its normal channels. Theaves of the great movement abate, and on the calm surface eddiesre formed in which float the diplomatists, who imagine that they haveaused the floods to abate.
	But the smooth sea again suddenly becomes disturbed. 	As the sun and each atom of ether is a sphere complete in itself,nd yet at the same time only a part of a whole too immense for man toomprehend, so each individual has within himself his own aims and yetas them to serve a general purpose incomprehensible to man.
	A bee settling on a flower has stung a child. And the child isfraid of bees and declares that bees exist to sting people. A poetdmires the bee sucking from the chalice of a flower and says itxists to suck the fragrance of flowers. A beekeeper, seeing the beeollect pollen from flowers and carry it to the hive, says that itxists to gather honey. Another beekeeper who has studied the lifef the hive more closely says that the bee gathers pollen dust to feedhe young bees and rear a queen, and that it exists to perpetuatets race. A botanist notices that the bee flying with the pollen of male flower to a pistil fertilizes the latter, and sees in thishe purpose of the bee's existence. Another, observing the migrationf plants, notices that the bee helps in this work, and may say thatn this lies the purpose of the bee. But the ultimate purpose of theee is not exhausted by the first, the second, or any of the processeshe human mind can discern. The higher the human intellect rises inhe discovery of these purposes, the more obvious it becomes, that theltimate purpose is beyond our comprehension.
	All that is accessible to man is the relation of the life of the beeo other manifestations of life. And so it is with the purpose ofistoric characters and nations.EP1|CH5
	CHAPTER V

	CHAPTER VI

	CHAPTER VII
	In the winter of 1813 Nicholas married Princess Mary and moved toald Hills with his wife, his mother, and Sonya.

	CHAPTER X
	Natasha had married in the early spring of 1813, and in 1820 alreadyad three daughters besides a son for whom she had longed and whom sheas now nursing.
