	CHAPTER I
	History is the life of nations and of humanity. To seize and putnto words, to describe directly the life of humanity or even of aingle nation, appears impossible.
	The ancient historians all employed one and the same method toescribe and seize the apparently elusive- the life of a people.hey described the activity of individuals who ruled the people, andegarded the activity of those men as representing the activity of thehole nation.
	The question: how did individuals make nations act as they wishednd by what was the will of these individuals themselves guided? thencients met by recognizing a divinity which subjected the nationso the will of a chosen man, and guided the will of that chosen man sos to accomplish ends that were predestined.
	For the ancients these questions were solved by a belief in theirect participation of the Deity in human affairs.
	Modern history, in theory, rejects both these principles.
	It would seem that having rejected the belief of the ancients inan's subjection to the Deity and in a predetermined aim towardhich nations are led, modern history should study not theanifestations of power but the causes that produce it. But modernistory has not done this. Having in theory rejected the view heldy the ancients, it still follows them in practice.
	Instead of men endowed with divine authority and directly guidedy the will of God, modern history has given us either heroesndowed with extraordinary, superhuman capacities, or simply men ofery various kinds, from monarchs to journalists, who lead the masses.nstead of the former divinely appointed aims of the Jewish, Greek, oroman nations, which ancient historians regarded as representing therogress of humanity, modern history has postulated its own aims-he welfare of the French, German, or English people, or, in itsighest abstraction, the welfare and civilization of humanity ineneral, by which is usually meant that of the peoples occupying amall northwesterly portion of a large continent.
	Modern history has rejected the beliefs of the ancients withouteplacing them by a new conception, and the logic of the situation hasbliged the historians, after they had apparently rejected theivine authority of the kings and the "fate" of the ancients, to reachhe same conclusion by another road, that is, to recognize (1) nationsuided by individual men, and (2) the existence of a known aim tohich these nations and humanity at large are tending.
	At the basis of the works of all the modern historians from Gibbono Buckle, despite their seeming disagreements and the apparentovelty of their outlooks, lie those two old, unavoidable assumptions.
	In the first place the historian describes the activity ofndividuals who in his opinion have directed humanity (one historianonsiders only monarchs, generals, and ministers as being such men,hile another includes also orators, learned men, reformers,hilosophers, and poets). Secondly, it is assumed that the goal towardhich humanity is being led is known to the historians: to one of themhis goal is the greatness of the Roman, Spanish, or French realm;o another it is liberty, equality, and a certain kind of civilizationf a small corner of the world called Europe.
	In 1789 a ferment arises in Paris; it grows, spreads, and isxpressed by a movement of peoples from west to east. Several times itoves eastward and collides with a countermovement from the eastestward. In 1812 it reaches its extreme limit, Moscow, and then, withemarkable symmetry, a countermovement occurs from east to west,ttracting to it, as the first movement had done, the nations ofiddle Europe. The counter movement reaches the starting point ofhe first movement in the west- Paris- and subsides.
	During that twenty-year period an immense number of fields were leftntilled, houses were burned, trade changed its direction, millions ofen migrated, were impoverished, or were enriched, and millions ofhristian men professing the law of love of their fellows slew onenother.
	What does all this mean? Why did it happen? What made those peopleurn houses and slay their fellow men? What were the causes of thesevents? What force made men act so? These are the instinctive,lain, and most legitimate questions humanity asks itself when itncounters the monuments and tradition of that period.
	For a reply to these questions the common sense of mankind turnso the science of history, whose aim is to enable nations and humanityo know themselves.
	If history had retained the conception of the ancients it would haveaid that God, to reward or punish his people, gave Napoleon power andirected his will to the fulfillment of the divine ends, and thateply, would have been clear and complete. One might believe orisbelieve in the divine significance of Napoleon, but for anyoneelieving in it there would have been nothing unintelligible in theistory of that period, nor would there have been any contradictions.

	CHAPTER II
	What force moves the nations?
	Biographical historians and historians of separate nationsnderstand this force as a power inherent in heroes and rulers. Inheir narration events occur solely by the will of a Napoleon, andlexander, or in general of the persons they describe. The answersiven by this kind of historian to the question of what force causesvents to happen are satisfactory only as long as there is but oneistorian to each event. As soon as historians of differentationalities and tendencies begin to describe the same event, theeplies they give immediately lose all meaning, for this force isnderstood by them all not only differently but often in quiteontradictory ways. One historian says that an event was produced byapoleon's power, another that it was produced by Alexander's, a thirdhat it was due to the power of some other person. Besides this,istorians of that kind contradict each other even in theirtatement as to the force on which the authority of some particularerson was based. Thiers, a Bonapartist, says that Napoleon's poweras based on his virtue and genius. Lanfrey, a Republican, says it wasased on his trickery and deception of the people. So the historiansf this class, by mutually destroying one another's positions, destroyhe understanding of the force which produces events, and furnish noeply to history's essential question.
	Writers of universal history who deal with all the nations seem toecognize how erroneous is the specialist historians' view of theorce which produces events. They do not recognize it as a powernherent in heroes and rulers, but as the resultant of aultiplicity of variously directed forces. In describing a war orhe subjugation of a people, a general historian looks for the causef the event not in the power of one man, but in the interaction ofany persons connected with the event.
	According to this view the power of historical personages,epresented as the product of many forces, can no longer, it wouldeem, be regarded as a force that itself produces events. Yet inost cases universal historians still employ the conception of powers a force that itself produces events, and treat it as their cause.n their exposition, an historic character is first the product of hisime, and his power only the resultant of various forces, and then hisower is itself a force producing events. Gervinus, Schlosser, andthers, for instance, at one time prove Napoleon to be a product ofhe Revolution, of the ideas of 1789 and so forth, and at anotherlainly say that the campaign of 1812 and other things they do notike were simply the product of Napoleon's misdirected will, andhat the very ideas of 1789 were arrested in their development byapoleon's caprice. The ideas of the Revolution and the general temperf the age produced Napoleon's power. But Napoleon's poweruppressed the ideas of the Revolution and the general temper of thege.
	This curious contradiction is not accidental. Not only does it occurt every step, but the universal historians' accounts are all madep of a chain of such contradictions. This contradiction occursecause after entering the field of analysis the universalistorians stop halfway.
	To find component forces equal to the composite or resultantorce, the sum of the components must equal the resultant. Thisondition is never observed by the universal historians, and so toxplain the resultant forces they are obliged to admit, in addition tohe insufficient components, another unexplained force affecting theesultant action.
	Specialist historians describing the campaign of 1813 or theestoration of the Bourbons plainly assert that these events wereroduced by the will of Alexander. But the universal historianervinus, refuting this opinion of the specialist historian, trieso prove that the campaign of 1813 and the restoration of the Bourbonsere due to other things beside Alexander's will- such as the activityf Stein, Metternich, Madame de Stael, Talleyrand, Fichtehateaubriand, and others. The historian evidently decomposeslexander's power into the components: Talleyrand, Chateaubriand,nd the rest- but the sum of the components, that is, the interactionsf Chateaubriand, Talleyrand, Madame de Stael, and the others,vidently does not equal the resultant, namely the phenomenon ofillions of Frenchmen submitting to the Bourbons. Thathateaubriand, Madame de Stael, and others spoke certain words tone another only affected their mutual relations but does notccount for the submission of millions. And therefore to explain howrom these relations of theirs the submission of millions of peopleesulted- that is, how component forces equal to one A gave aesultant equal to a thousand times A- the historian is againbliged to fall back on power- the force he had denied- and toecognize it as the resultant of the forces, that is, he has todmit an unexplained force acting on the resultant. And that is justhat the universal historians do, and consequently they not onlyontradict the specialist historians but contradict themselves.
	Peasants having no clear idea of the cause of rain, say, accordingo whether they want rain or fine weather: "The wind has blown thelouds away," or, "The wind has brought up the clouds." And in theame way the universal historians sometimes, when it pleases themnd fits in with their theory, say that power is the result of events,nd sometimes, when they want to prove something else, say thatower produces events.
	A third class of historians- the so-called historians of culture-ollowing the path laid down by the universal historians who sometimesccept writers and ladies as forces producing events- again takehat force to be something quite different. They see it in what isalled culture- in mental activity.
	The historians of culture are quite consistent in regard to theirrogenitors, the writers of universal histories, for if historicalvents may be explained by the fact that certain persons treated onenother in such and such ways, why not explain them by the fact thatuch and such people wrote such and such books? Of the immenseumber of indications accompanying every vital phenomenon, theseistorians select the indication of intellectual activity and say thathis indication is the cause. But despite their endeavors to provehat the cause of events lies in intellectual activity, only by areat stretch can one admit that there is any connection betweenntellectual activity and the movement of peoples, and in no casean one admit that intellectual activity controls people's actions,or that view is not confirmed by such facts as the very cruel murdersf the French Revolution resulting from the doctrine of the equalityf man, or the very cruel wars and executions resulting from thereaching of love.
	But even admitting as correct all the cunningly devised argumentsith which these histories are filled- admitting that nations areoverned by some undefined force called an idea- history's essentialuestion still remains unanswered, and to the former power of monarchsnd to the influence of advisers and other people introduced by theniversal historians, another, newer force- the idea- is added, theonnection of which with the masses needs explanation. It isossible to understand that Napoleon had power and so events occurred;ith some effort one may even conceive that Napoleon together withther influences was the cause of an event; but how a book, Le Contratocial, had the effect of making Frenchmen begin to drown onenother cannot be understood without an explanation of the causalexus of this new force with the event.
	Undoubtedly some relation exists between all who liveontemporaneously, and so it is possible to find some connectionetween the intellectual activity of men and their historicalovements, just as such a connection may be found between theovements of humanity and commerce, handicraft, gardening, or anythinglse you please. Only the followingonsiderations can have led the historians to such a conclusion: (1)hat history is written by learned men, and so it is natural andgreeable for them to think that the activity of their classupplies the basis of the movement of all humanity, just as aimilar belief is natural and agreeable to traders, agriculturists,nd soldiers (if they do not express it, that is merely becauseraders and soldiers do not write history), and (2) that spiritualctivity, enlightenment, civilization, culture, ideas, are allndistinct, indefinite conceptions under whose banner it is veryasy to use words having a still less definite meaning, and whichan therefore be readily introduced into any theory.

	CHAPTER III
	A locomotive is moving. Someone asks: "What moves it?" A peasantays the devil moves it. Another man says the locomotive moves becausets wheels go round. A third asserts that the cause of its movementies in the smoke which the wind carries away.
	The peasant is irrefutable. He has devised a complete explanation.o refute him someone would have to prove to him that there is noevil, or another peasant would have to explain to him that it isot the devil but a German, who moves the locomotive. Only then, as result of the contradiction, will they see that they are both wrong.ut the man who says that the movement of the wheels is the causeefutes himself, for having once begun to analyze he ought to go onnd explain further why the wheels go round; and till he has reachedhe ultimate cause of the movement of the locomotive in the pressuref steam in the boiler, he has no right to stop in his search forhe cause. The man who explains the movement of the locomotive byhe smoke that is carried back has noticed that the wheels do notupply an explanation and has taken the first sign that occurs toim and in his turn has offered that as an explanation.
	The only conception that can explain the movement of theocomotive is that of a force commensurate with the movement observed.
	The only conception that can explain the movement of the peopless that of some force commensurate with the whole movement of theeoples.
	Yet to supply this conception various historians take forces ofifferent kinds, all of which are incommensurate with the movementbserved. Some see it as a force directly inherent in heroes, as theeasant sees the devil in the locomotive; others as a forceesulting from several other forces, like the movement of theheels; others again as an intellectual influence, like the smoke thats blown away.
	So long as histories are written of separate individuals, whetheraesars, Alexanders, Luthers, or Voltaires, and not the histories ofll, absolutely all those who take part in an event, it is quitempossible to describe the movement of humanity without the conceptionf a force compelling men to direct their activity toward a certainnd. And the only such conception known to historians is that ofower.
	This conception is the one handle by means of which the materialf history, as at present expounded, can be dealt with, and anyone whoreaks that handle off, as Buckle did, without finding some otherethod of treating historical material, merely deprives himself of thene possible way of dealing with it. The necessity of the conceptionf power as an explanation of historical events is best demonstratedy the universal historians and historians of culture themselves,or they professedly reject that conception but inevitably haveecourse to it at every step.
	In dealing with humanity's inquiry, the science of history up to nows like money in circulation- paper money and coin. The biographiesnd special national histories are like paper money. They can besed and can circulate and fulfill their purpose without harm tonyone and even advantageously, as long as no one asks what is theecurity behind them. You need only forget to ask how the will oferoes produces events, and such histories as Thiers' will benteresting and instructive and may perhaps even possess a tinge ofoetry. But just as doubts of the real value of paper money ariseither because, being easy to make, too much of it gets made orecause people try to exchange it for gold, so also doubtsoncerning the real value of such histories arise either because tooany of them are written or because in his simplicity of heart someonenquires: by what force did Napoleon do this?- that is, wants toxchange the current paper money for the real gold of actualomprehension.
	The writers of universal histories and of the history of culture areike people who, recognizing the defects of paper money, decide toubstitute for it money made of metal that has not the specificravity of gold. It may indeed make jingling coin, but will do no morehan that. Paper money may deceive the ignorant, but nobody iseceived by tokens of base metal that have no value but merely jingle.s gold is gold only if it is serviceable not merely for exchangeut also for use, so universal historians will be valuable only whenhey can reply to history's essential question: what is power? Theniversal historians give contradictory replies to that question,hile the historians of culture evade it and answer something quiteifferent. And as counters of imitation gold can be used only among group of people who agree to accept them as gold, or among those whoo not know the nature of gold, so universal historians and historiansf culture, not answering humanity's essential question, serve asurrency for some purposes of their own, only in universities andmong the mass of readers who have a taste for what they call "seriouseading."EP2|CH4
	CHAPTER IV
	Having abandoned the conception of the ancients as to the divineubjection of the will of a nation to some chosen man and theubjection of that man's will to the Deity, history cannot withoutontradictions take a single step till it has chosen one of twohings: either a return to the former belief in the directntervention of the Deity in human affairs or a definite explanationf the meaning of the force producing historical events and termedpower."
	A return to the first is impossible, the belief has beenestroyed; and so it is essential to explain what is meant by power.
	Napoleon ordered an army to be raised and go to war. We are soccustomed to that idea and have become so used to it that theuestion: why did six hundred thousand men go to fight when Napoleonttered certain words, seems to us senseless. He had the power ando what he ordered was done.
	This reply is quite satisfactory if we believe that the power wasiven him by God. But as soon as we do not admit that, it becomesssential to determine what is this power of one man over others.
	It cannot be the direct physical power of a strong man over a weakne- a domination based on the application or threat of physicalorce, like the power of Hercules; nor can it be based on the effectf moral force, as in their simplicity some historians think who sayhat the leading figures in history are heroes, that is, men giftedith a special strength of soul and mind called genius. This powerannot be based on the predominance of moral strength, for, not toention heroes such as Napoleon about whose moral qualities opinionsiffer widely, history shows us that neither a Louis XI nor aetternich, who ruled over millions of people, had any particularoral qualities, but on the contrary were generally morally weakerhan any of the millions they ruled over.
	If the source of power lies neither in the physical nor in the moralualities of him who possesses it, it must evidently be looked forlsewhere- in the relation to the people of the man who wields theower.
	And that is how power is understood by the science of jurisprudence,hat exchange bank of history which offers to exchange history'snderstanding of power for true gold.
	Power is the collective will of the people transferred, by expressedr tacit consent, to their chosen rulers.
	In the domain of jurisprudence, which consists of discussions of how state and power might be arranged were it possible for all that toe arranged, it is all very clear; but when applied to history thatefinition of power needs explanation.
	The science of jurisprudence regards the state and power as thencients regarded fire- namely, as something existing absolutely.ut for history, the state and power are merely phenomena, just as forodern physics fire is not an element but a phenomenon.
	From this fundamental difference between the view held by historynd that held by jurisprudence, it follows that jurisprudence can tellinutely how in its opinion power should be constituted and whatower- existing immutably outside time- is, but to history's questionsbout the meaning of the mutations of power in time it can answerothing.
	If power be the collective will of the people transferred to theiruler, was Pugachev a representative of the will of the people? Ifot, then why was Napoleon I? Why was Napoleon III a criminal whene was taken prisoner at Boulogne, and why, later on, were thoseriminals whom he arrested?
	Do palace revolutions- in which sometimes only two or three peopleake part- transfer the will of the people to a new ruler? Innternational relations, is the will of the people also transferred toheir conqueror? Was the will of the Confederation of the Rhineransferred to Napoleon in 1806? Was the will of the Russian peopleransferred to Napoleon in 1809, when our army in alliance with therench went to fight the Austrians?
	To these questions three answers are possible:
	Either to assume (1) that the will of the people is alwaysnconditionally transferred to the ruler or rulers they have chosen,nd that therefore every emergence of a new power, every strugglegainst the power once appointed, should be absolutely regarded asn infringement of the real power; or (2) that the will of theeople is transferred to the rulers conditionally, under definitend known conditions, and to show that all limitations, conflicts, andven destructions of power result from a nonobservance by the rulersf the conditions under which their power was entrusted to them; or3) that the will of the people is delegated to the rulersonditionally, but that the conditions are unknown and indefinite, andhat the appearance of several authorities, their struggles andheir falls, result solely from the greater or lesser fulfillment byhe rulers of these unknown conditions on which the will of the peoples transferred from some people to others.
	And these are the three ways in which the historians do explainhe relation of the people to their rulers.
	Some historians- those biographical and specialist historianslready referred to- in their simplicity failing to understand theuestion of the meaning of power, seem to consider that the collectiveill of the people is unconditionally transferred to historicalersons, and therefore when describing some single state they assumehat particular power to be the one absolute and real power, andhat any other force opposing this is not a power but a violation ofower- mere violence.
	Their theory, suitable for primitive and peaceful periods ofistory, has the inconvenience- in application to complex and stormyeriods in the life of nations during which various powers ariseimultaneously and struggle with one another- that a Legitimististorian will prove that the National Convention, the Directory,nd Bonaparte were mere infringers of the true power, while aepublican and a Bonapartist will prove: the one that the Conventionnd the other that the Empire was the real power, and that all thethers were violations of power. Evidently the explanationsurnished by these historians being mutually contradictory can onlyatisfy young children.
	Recognizing the falsity of this view of history, another set ofistorians say that power rests on a conditional delegation of theill of the people to their rulers, and that historical leaders haveower only conditionally on carrying out the program that the willf the people has by tacit agreement prescribed to them. But what thisrogram consists in these historians do not say, or if they do theyontinually contradict one another.
	Each historian, according to his view of what constitutes a nation'srogress, looks for these conditions in the greatness, wealth,reedom, or enlightenment of citizens of France or some other country.ut not to mention the historians' contradictions as to the naturef this program- or even admitting that some one general program ofhese conditions exists- the facts of history almost always contradicthat theory. If the conditions under which power is entrustedonsist in the wealth, freedom, and enlightenment of the people, hows it that Louis XIV and Ivan the Terrible end their reignsranquilly, while Louis XVI and Charles I are executed by theireople? To this question historians reply that Louis XIV's activity,ontrary to the program, reacted on Louis XVI. But why did it noteact on Louis XIV or on Louis XV- why should it react just on LouisVI? And what is the time limit for such reactions? To these questionshere are and can be no answers. Equally little does this view explainhy for several centuries the collective will is not withdrawn fromertain rulers and their heirs, and then suddenly during a period ofifty years is transferred to the Convention, to the Directory, toapoleon, to Alexander, to Louis XVIII, to Napoleon again, toharles X, to Louis Philippe, to a Republican government, and toapoleon III. When explaining these rapid transfers of the people'sill from from one individual to another, especially in view ofnternational relations, conquests, and alliances, the historiansre obliged to admit that some of these transfers are not normalelegations of the people's will but are accidents dependent onunning, on mistakes, on craft, or on the weakness of a diplomatist, auler, or a party leader. So that the greater part of the events ofistory- civil wars, revolutions, and conquests- are presented byhese historians not as the results of free transferences of theeople's will, but as results of the ill-directed will of one orore individuals, that is, once again, as usurpations of power. And sohese historians also see and admit historical events which arexceptions to the theory.
	These historians resemble a botanist who, having noticed that somelants grow from seeds producing two cotyledons, should insist thatll that grows does so by sprouting into two leaves, and that thealm, the mushroom, and even the oak, which blossom into full growthnd no longer resemble two leaves, are deviations from the theory.

	CHAPTER V
	The life of the nations is not contained in the lives of a fewen, for the connection between those men and the nations has not beenound. 	CHAPTER VI
	Only the expression of the will of the Deity, not dependent on time,an relate to a whole series of events occurring over a period ofears or centuries, and only the Deity, independent of everything, cany His sole will determine the direction of humanity's movement; butan acts in time and himself takes part in what occurs.

	This relation of the commander to those he commands is just whats called power. This relation consists in the following:
	For common action people always unite in certain combinations, inhich regardless of the difference of the aims set for the commonction, the relation between those taking part in it is always theame.
	Men uniting in these combinations always assume such relationsoward one another that the larger number take a more direct share,nd the smaller number a less direct share, in the collective actionor which they have combined.

	Every army is composed of lower grades of the service- the ranknd file- of whom there are always the greatest number; of the nextigher military rank- corporals and noncommissioned officers of whomhere are fewer, and of still-higher officers of whom there aretill fewer, and so on to the highest military command which isoncentrated in one person.

	The soldiers, of whom there are the most, form the lower sectionf the cone and its base. 	CHAPTER VII
	When an event is taking place people express their opinions andishes about it, and as the event results from the collective activityf many people, some one of the opinions or wishes expressed is sureo be fulfilled if but approximately. 	In whatever direction a ship moves, the flow of the waves it cutsill always be noticeable ahead of it. To those on board the shiphe movement of those waves will be the only perceptible motion.

	Examining only those expressions of the will of historical personshich, as commands, were related to events, historians have assumedhat the events depended on those commands. But examining the eventshemselves and the connection in which the historical persons stood tohe people, we have found that they and their orders were dependent onvents. The incontestable proof of this deduction is that, howeverany commands were issued, the event does not take place unlesshere are other causes for it, but as soon as an event occurs- be ithat it may- then out of all the continually expressed wishes ofifferent people some will always be found which by their meaningnd their time of utterance are related as commands to the events.
	Arriving at this conclusion we can reply directly and positivelyo these two essential questions of history:
	(1) What is power?
	(2) What force produces the movement of the nations?
	(1) Power is the relation of a given person to other individuals, inhich the more this person expresses opinions, predictions, andustifications of the collective action that is performed, the less isis participation in that action.
	(2) The movement of nations is caused not by power, nor byntellectual activity, nor even by a combination of the two asistorians have supposed, but by the activity of all the people whoarticipate in the events, and who always combine in such a way thathose taking the largest direct share in the event take onhemselves the least responsibility and vice versa.

	Or in other words, the conception of a cause is inapplicable tohe phenomena we are examining.
	In the last analysis we reach the circle of infinity- that finalimit to which in every domain of thought man's reason arrives if its not playing with the subject. Electricity produces heat, heatroduces electricity. Atoms attract each other and atoms repel onenother.

	CHAPTER VIII
	If history dealt only with external phenomena, the establishmentf this simple and obvious law would suffice and we should haveinished our argument. But the law of history relates to man. Aarticle of matter cannot tell us that it does not feel the law ofttraction or repulsion and that that law is untrue, but man, who ishe subject of history, says plainly: I am free and am therefore notubject to the law.
	The presence of the problem of man's free will, thoughnexpressed, is felt at every step of history.
	All seriously thinking historians have involuntarily encounteredhis question. All the contradictions and obscurities of history andhe false path historical science has followed are due solely to theack of a solution of that question.
	If the will of every man were free, that is, if each man could acts he pleased, all history would be a series of disconnectedncidents.
	If in a thousand years even one man in a million could act freely,hat is, as he chose, it is evident that one single free act of thatan's in violation of the laws governing human action would destroyhe possibility of the existence of any laws for the whole ofumanity.
	If there be a single law governing the actions of men, free willannot exist, for then man's will is subject to that law.
	In this contradiction lies the problem of free will, which from mostncient times has occupied the best human minds and from mostncient times has been presented in its whole tremendous significance.
	The problem is that regarding man as a subject of observation fromhatever point of view- theological, historical, ethical, orhilosophic- we find a general law of necessity to which he (likell that exists) is subject. 	If, observing himself, man sees that his will is always directedy one and the same law (whether he observes the necessity of takingood, using his brain, or anything else) he cannot recognize thisever-varying direction of his will otherwise than as a limitationf it. Were it not free it could not be limited. A man's will seems toim to be limited just because he is not conscious of it except asree.
	You say: I am not and am not free. But I have lifted my hand and lett fall. Everyone understands that this illogical reply is anrrefutable demonstration of freedom.
	That reply is the expression of a consciousness that is notubject to reason.

	A series of experiments and arguments proves to every man that he,s an object of observation, is subject to certain laws, and manubmits to them and never resists the laws of gravity ormpermeability once he has become acquainted with them. Having learned from experiment andrgument that a stone falls downwards, a man indubitably believes thisnd always expects the law that he has learned to be fulfilled.
	But learning just as certainly that his will is subject to laws,e does not and cannot believe this.
	However often experiment and reasoning may show a man that under theame conditions and with the same character he will do the samehing as before, yet when under the same conditions and with theame character he approaches for the thousandth time the action thatlways ends in the same way, he feels as certainly convinced as beforehe experiment that he can act as he pleases. Every man, savage orage, however incontestably reason and experiment may prove to himhat it is impossible to imagine two different courses of action inrecisely the same conditions, feels that without this irrationalonception (which constitutes the essence of freedom) he cannotmagine life. He feels that however impossible it may be, it is so,or without this conception of freedom not only would he be unableo understand life, but he would be unable to live for a singleoment.
	He could not live, because all man's efforts, all his impulses toife, are only efforts to increase freedom. 	A man having no freedom cannot be conceived of except as deprived ofife.

	Man is the creation of an all-powerful, all-good, and all-seeingod. What is sin, the conception of which arises from theonsciousness of man's freedom? That is a question for theology.

	Only in our self-confident day of the popularization of knowledge-hanks to that most powerful engine of ignorance, the diffusion ofrinted matter- has the question of the freedom of will been put on level on which the question itself cannot exist. 	If men descended from the apes at an unknown period of time, that iss comprehensible as that they were made from a handful of earth at certain period of time (in the first case the unknown quantity ishe time, in the second case it is the origin); and the question ofow man's consciousness of freedom is to be reconciled with the law ofecessity to which he is subject cannot be solved by comparativehysiology and zoology, for in a frog, a rabbit, or an ape, we canbserve only the muscular nervous activity, but in man we observeonsciousness as well as the muscular and nervous activity.

	CHAPTER IX
	For the solution of the question of free will or inevitability,istory has this advantage over other branches of knowledge in whichhe question is dealt with, that for history this question does notefer to the essence of man's free will but its manifestation in theast and under certain conditions.
	In regard to this question, history stands to the other sciencess experimental science stands to abstract science.
	The subject for history is not man's will itself but ourresentation of it.
	And so for history, the insoluble mystery presented by thencompatibility of free will and inevitability does not exist as itoes for theology, ethics, and philosophy. History surveys aresentation of man's life in which the union of these twoontradictions has already taken place.
	In actual life each historic event, each human action, is verylearly and definitely understood without any sense ofontradiction, although each event presents itself as partly freend partly compulsory.
	To solve the question of how freedom and necessity are combinednd what constitutes the essence of these two conceptions, thehilosophy of history can and should follow a path contrary to thataken by other sciences. Instead of first defining the conceptionsf freedom and inevitability in themselves, and then ranging thehenomena of life under those definitions, history should deduce aefinition of the conception of freedom and inevitability themselvesrom the immense quantity of phenomena of which it is cognizant andhat always appear dependent on these two elements.
	Whatever presentation of the activity of many men or of anndividual we may consider, we always regard it as the result partlyf man's free will and partly of the law of inevitability.
	Whether we speak of the migration of the peoples and thencursions of the barbarians, or of the decrees of Napoleon III, or ofomeone's action an hour ago in choosing one direction out ofeveral for his walk, we are unconscious of any contradiction. Theegree of freedom and inevitability governing the actions of theseeople is clearly defined for us.
	Our conception of the degree of freedom often varies according toifferences in the point of view from which we regard the event, butvery human action appears to us as a certain combination of freedomnd inevitability. In every action we examine we see a certain measuref freedom and a certain measure of inevitability. And always the morereedom we see in any action the less inevitability do we perceive,nd the more inevitability the less freedom.
	The proportion of freedom to inevitability decreases and increasesccording to the point of view from which the action is regarded,ut their relation is always one of inverse proportion.
	A sinking man who clutches at another and drowns him; or a hungryother exhausted by feeding her baby, who steals some food; or a manrained to discipline who on duty at the word of command kills aefenseless man- seem less guilty, that is, less free and more subjecto the law of necessity, to one who knows the circumstances in whichhese people were placed, and more free to one who does not knowhat the man was himself drowning, that the mother was hungry, thathe soldier was in the ranks, and so on. Similarly a man who committed murder twenty years ago and has since lived peaceably and harmlesslyn society seems less guilty and his action more due to the law ofnevitability, to someone who considers his action after twentyears have elapsed than to one who examined it the day after it wasommitted. And in the same way every action of an insane, intoxicated,r highly excited man appears less free and more inevitable to one whonows the mental condition of him who committed the action, andeems more free and less inevitable to one who does not know it. Inll these cases the conception of freedom is increased or diminishednd the conception of compulsion is correspondingly decreased orncreased, according to the point of view from which the action isegarded. So that the greater the conception of necessity themaller the conception of freedom and vice versa.
	Religion, the common sense of mankind, the science of jurisprudence,nd history itself understand alike this relation between necessitynd freedom.
	All cases without exception in which our conception of freedom andecessity is increased and diminished depend on three considerations:
	(1) The relation to the external world of the man who commits theeeds.
	(2) His relation to time.
	(3) His relation to the causes leading to the action.
	The first consideration is the clearness of our perception of thean's relation to the external world and the greater or lesserlearness of our understanding of the definite position occupied byhe man in relation to everything coexisting with him. This is whatakes it evident that a drowning man is less free and more subjecto necessity than one standing on dry ground, and that makes thections of a man closely connected with others in a thicklyopulated district, or of one bound by family, official, or businessuties, seem certainly less free and more subject to necessity thanhose of a man living in solitude and seclusion.
	If we consider a man alone, apart from his relation to everythinground him, each action of his seems to us free. But if we see hiselation to anything around him, if we see his connection withnything whatever- with a man who speaks to him, a book he reads,he work on which he is engaged, even with the air he breathes orhe light that falls on the things about him- we see that each ofhese circumstances has an influence on him and controls at least someide of his activity. And the more we perceive of these influences theore our conception of his freedom diminishes and the more ouronception of the necessity that weighs on him increases.
	The second consideration is the more or less evident time relationf the man to the world and the clearness of our perception of thelace the man's action occupies in time. That is the ground whichakes the fall of the first man, resulting in the production of theuman race, appear evidently less free than a man's entry intoarriage today. It is the reason why the life and activity of peopleho lived centuries ago and are connected with me in time cannoteem to me as free as the life of a contemporary, the consequencesf which are still unknown to me.
	The degree of our conception of freedom or inevitability dependsn this respect on the greater or lesser lapse of time between theerformance of the action and our judgment of it.
	If I examine an act I performed a moment ago in approximately theame circumstances as those I am in now, my action appears to mendoubtedly free. But if I examine an act performed a month ago,hen being in different circumstances, I cannot help recognizinghat if that act had not been committed much that resulted from it-ood, agreeable, and even essential- would not have taken place. If reflect on an action still more remote, ten years ago or more,hen the consequences of my action are still plainer to me and Iind it hard to imagine what would have happened had that action noteen performed. The farther I go back in memory, or what is the samehing the farther I go forward in my judgment, the more doubtfulecomes my belief in the freedom of my action.
	In history we find a very similar progress of convictiononcerning the part played by free will in the general affairs ofumanity. A contemporary event seems to us to be indubitably the doingf all the known participants, but with a more remote event we alreadyee its inevitable results which prevent our considering anything elseossible. And the farther we go back in examining events the lessrbitrary do they appear.
	The Austro-Prussian war appears to us undoubtedly the result ofhe crafty conduct of Bismarck, and so on. The Napoleonic wars stilleem to us, though already questionably, to be the outcome of theireroes' will. But in the Crusades we already see an event occupyingts definite place in history and without which we cannot imaginehe modern history of Europe, though to the chroniclers of therusades that event appeared as merely due to the will of certaineople. In regard to the migration of the peoples it does not enternyone's head today to suppose that the renovation of the Europeanorld depended on Attila's caprice. The farther back in history thebject of our observation lies, the more doubtful does the free willf those concerned in the event become and the more manifest the lawf inevitability.
	The third consideration is the degree to which we apprehend thatndless chain of causation inevitably demanded by reason, in whichach phenomenon comprehended, and therefore man's every action, mustave its definite place as a result of what has gone before and as aause of what will follow.
	The better we are acquainted with the physiological,sychological, and historical laws deduced by observation and by whichan is controlled, and the more correctly we perceive thehysiological, psychological, and historical causes of the action, andhe simpler the action we are observing and the less complex theharacter and mind of the man in question, the more subject tonevitability and the less free do our actions and those of othersppear.
	When we do not at all understand the cause of an action, whether arime, a good action, or even one that is simply nonmoral, wescribe a greater amount of freedom to it. In the case of a crime weost urgently demand the punishment for such an act; in the case of virtuous act we rate its merit most highly. In an indifferent casee recognize in it more individuality, originality, andndependence. But if even one of the innumerable causes of the acts known to us we recognize a certain element of necessity and areess insistent on punishment for the crime, or the acknowledgment ofhe merit of the virtuous act, or the freedom of the apparentlyriginal action. That a criminal was reared among male factorsitigates his fault in our eyes. The self-sacrifice of a father orother, or self-sacrifice with the possibility of a reward, is moreomprehensible than gratuitous self-sacrifice, and therefore seemsess deserving of sympathy and less the result of free will. Theounder of a sect or party, or an inventor, impresses us less whene know how or by what the way was prepared for his activity. If weave a large range of examples, if our observation is constantlyirected to seeking the correlation of cause and effect in people'sctions, their actions appear to us more under compulsion and lessree the more correctly we connect the effects with the causes. Ife examined simple actions and had a vast number of such actions underbservation, our conception of their inevitability would be stillreater. The dishonest conduct of the son of a dishonest father, theisconduct of a woman who had fallen into bad company, a drunkard'selapse into drunkenness, and so on are actions that seem to us lessree the better we understand their cause. If the man whose actions were considering is on a very low stage of mental development, like ahild, a madman, or a simpleton- then, knowing the causes of the actnd the simplicity of the character and intelligence in question, weee so large an element of necessity and so little free will that asoon as we know the cause prompting the action we can foretell theesult.
	On these three considerations alone is based the conception ofrresponsibility for crimes and the extenuating circumstances admittedy all legislative codes. The responsibility appears greater or lessccording to our greater or lesser knowledge of the circumstances inhich the man was placed whose action is being judged, and accordingo the greater or lesser interval of time between the commission ofhe action and its investigation, and according to the greater oresser understanding of the causes that led to the action.EP2|CH10
	CHAPTER X
	Thus our conception of free will and inevitability graduallyiminishes or increases according to the greater or lesseronnection with the external world, the greater or lesser remotenessf time, and the greater or lesser dependence on the causes inelation to which we contemplate a man's life.
	So that if we examine the case of a man whose connection with thexternal world is well known, where the time between the action andts examination is great, and where the causes of the action areost accessible, we get the conception of a maximum of inevitabilitynd a minimum of free will. If we examine a man little dependent onxternal conditions, whose action was performed very recently, and theauses of whose action are beyond our ken, we get the conception of minimum of inevitability and a maximum of freedom.
	In neither case- however we may change our point of view, howeverlain we may make to ourselves the connection between the man andhe external world, however inaccessible it may be to us, however longr short the period of time, however intelligible orncomprehensible the causes of the action may be- can we ever conceiveither complete freedom or complete necessity.
	(1) To whatever degree we may imagine a man to be exempt from thenfluence of the external world, we never get a conception ofreedom in space. Every human action is inevitably conditioned by whaturrounds him and by his own body. I lift my arm and let it fall. Myction seems to me free; but asking myself whether I could raise myrm in every direction, I see that I raised it in the direction inhich there was least obstruction to that action either from thingsround me or from the construction of my own body. I chose one outf all the possible directions because in it there were fewestbstacles. For my action to be free it was necessary that it shouldncounter no obstacles. To conceive of a man being free we mustmagine him outside space, which is evidently impossible.
	(2) However much we approximate the time of judgment to the timef the deed, we never get a conception of freedom in time. For if Ixamine an action committed a second ago I must still recognize its not being free, for it is irrevocably linked to the moment at whicht was committed. Can I lift my arm? I lift it, but ask myself:ould I have abstained from lifting my arm at the moment that haslready passed? To convince myself of this I do not lift it the nextoment. But I am not now abstaining from doing so at the firstoment when I asked the question. Time has gone by which I could notetain, the arm I then lifted is no longer the same as the arm I nowefrain from lifting, nor is the air in which I lifted it the samehat now surrounds me. The moment in which the first movement was mades irrevocable, and at that moment I could make only one movement, andhatever movement I made would be the only one. That I did not lift myrm a moment later does not prove that I could have abstained fromifting it then. And since I could make only one movement at thatingle moment of time, it could not have been any other. To imagine its free, it is necessary to imagine it in the present, on the boundaryetween the past and the future- that is, outside time, which ismpossible.
	(3) However much the difficulty of understanding the causes may bencreased, we never reach a conception of complete freedom, that is,n absence of cause. However inaccessible to us may be the cause ofhe expression of will in any action, our own or another's, theirst demand of reason is the assumption of and search for a cause,or without a cause no phenomenon is conceivable. I raise my arm toerform an action independently of any cause, but my wish to performn action without a cause is the cause of my action.
	But even if- imagining a man quite exempt from all influences,xamining only his momentary action in the present, unevoked by anyause- we were to admit so infinitely small a remainder ofnevitability as equaled zero, we should even then not have arrived athe conception of complete freedom in man, for a being uninfluenced byhe external world, standing outside of time and independent of cause,s no longer a man.
	In the same way we can never imagine the action of a man quiteevoid of freedom and entirely subject to the law of inevitability.
	(1) However we may increase our knowledge of the conditions of spacen which man is situated, that knowledge can never be complete, forhe number of those conditions is as infinite as the infinity ofpace. And therefore so long as not all the conditions influencing menre defined, there is no complete inevitability but a certaineasure of freedom remains.
	(2) However we may prolong the period of time between the actione are examining and the judgment upon it, that period will be finite,hile time is infinite, and so in this respect too there can nevere absolute inevitability.
	(3) However accessible may be the chain of causation of anyction, we shall never know the whole chain since it is endless, ando again we never reach absolute inevitability.
	But besides this, even if, admitting the remaining minimum ofreedom to equal zero, we assumed in some given case- as fornstance in that of a dying man, an unborn babe, or an idiot- completebsence of freedom, by so doing we should destroy the veryonception of man in the case we are examining, for as soon as theres no freedom there is also no man. And so the conception of thection of a man subject solely to the law of inevitability without anylement of freedom is just as impossible as the conception of aan's completely free action.
	And so to imagine the action of a man entirely subject to the law ofnevitability without any freedom, we must assume the knowledge ofn infinite number of space relations, an infinitely long period ofime, and an infinite series of causes.
	To imagine a man perfectly free and not subject to the law ofnevitability, we must imagine him all alone, beyond space, beyondime, and free from dependence on cause.
	In the first case, if inevitability were possible without freedom wehould have reached a definition of inevitability by the laws ofnevitability itself, that is, a mere form without content.
	In the second case, if freedom were possible without inevitabilitye should have arrived at unconditioned freedom beyond space, time,nd cause, which by the fact of its being unconditioned andnlimited would be nothing, or mere content without form.
	We should in fact have reached those two fundamentals of which man'shole outlook on the universe is constructed- the incomprehensiblessence of life, and the laws defining that essence.
	Reason says: (1) space with all the forms of matter that give itisibility is infinite, and cannot be imagined otherwise. (2) Times infinite motion without a moment of rest and is unthinkabletherwise. (3) The connection between cause and effect has noeginning and can have no end.
	Consciousness says: (1) I alone am, and all that exists is but me,onsequently I include space. (2) I measure flowing time by theixed moment of the present in which alone I am conscious of myself asiving, consequently I am outside time. (3) I am beyond cause, for Ieel myself to be the cause of every manifestation of my life.
	Reason gives expression to the laws of inevitability.onsciousness gives expression to the essence of freedom.
	Freedom not limited by anything is the essence of life, in man'sonsciousness. Inevitability without content is man's reason in itshree forms.
	Freedom is the thing examined. Inevitability is what examines.reedom is the content. Inevitability is the form.
	Only by separating the two sources of cognition, related to onenother as form to content, do we get the mutually exclusive andeparately incomprehensible conceptions of freedom and inevitability.
	Only by uniting them do we get a clear conception of man's life.
	Apart from these two concepts which in their union mutually definene another as form and content, no conception of life is possible.
	All that we know of the life of man is merely a certain relationf free will to inevitability, that is, of consciousness to the lawsf reason.
	All that we know of the external world of nature is only a certainelation of the forces of nature to inevitability, or of the essencef life to the laws of reason.
	The great natural forces lie outside us and we are not consciousf them; we call those forces gravitation, inertia, electricity,nimal force, and so on, but we are conscious of the force of lifen man and we call that freedom.
	But just as the force of gravitation, incomprehensible in itself butelt by every man, is understood by us only to the extent to whiche know the laws of inevitability to which it is subject (from theirst knowledge that all bodies have weight, up to Newton's law), sooo the force of free will, incomprehensible in itself but of whichveryone is conscious, is intelligible to us only in as far as we knowhe laws of inevitability to which it is subject (from the fact thatvery man dies, up to the knowledge of the most complex economic andistoric laws).
	All knowledge is merely a bringing of this essence of life under theaws of reason.
	Man's free will differs from every other force in that man isirectly conscious of it, but in the eyes of reason it in no wayiffers from any other force. The forces of gravitation,lectricity, or chemical affinity are only distinguished from onenother in that they are differently defined by reason. Just so theorce of man's free will is distinguished by reason from the otherorces of nature only by the definition reason gives it. Freedom,part from necessity, that is, apart from the laws of reason thatefine it, differs in no way from gravitation, or heat, or the forcehat makes things grow; for reason, it is only a momentary undefinableensation of life.
	And as the undefinable essence of the force moving the heavenlyodies, the undefinable essence of the forces of heat and electricity,r of chemical affinity, or of the vital force, forms the content ofstronomy, physics, chemistry, botany, zoology, and so on, just in theame way does the force of free will form the content of history.ut just as the subject of every science is the manifestation ofhis unknown essence of life while that essence itself can only be theubject of metaphysics, even the manifestation of the force of freeill in human beings in space, in time, and in dependence on causeorms the subject of history, while free will itself is the subject ofetaphysics.
	In the experimental sciences what we know we call the laws ofnevitability, what is unknown to us we call vital force. Vitalorce is only an expression for the unknown remainder over and abovehat we know of the essence of life.
	So also in history what is known to us we call laws ofnevitability, what is unknown we call free will. Free will is foristory only an expression for the unknown remainder of what we knowbout the laws of human life.EP2|CH11
	CHAPTER XI
	History examines the manifestations of man's free will in connectionith the external world in time and in dependence on cause, that is,t defines this freedom by the laws of reason, and so history is acience only in so far as this free will is defined by those laws.
	The recognition of man's free will as something capable ofnfluencing historical events, that is, as not subject to laws, is theame for history as the recognition of a free force moving theeavenly bodies would be for astronomy.
	That assumption would destroy the possibility of the existence ofaws, that is, of any science whatever. If there is even a single bodyoving freely, then the laws of Kepler and Newton are negatived and noonception of the movement of the heavenly bodies any longer exists.f any single action is due to free will, then not a single historicalaw can exist, nor any conception of historical events.
	For history, lines exist of the movement of human wills, one endf which is hidden in the unknown but at the other end of which aonsciousness of man's will in the present moves in space, time, andependence on cause.
	The more this field of motion spreads out before our eyes, theore evident are the laws of that movement. To discover and definehose laws is the problem of history.
	From the standpoint from which the science of history now regardsts subject on the path it now follows, seeking the causes of eventsn man's freewill, a scientific enunciation of those laws ismpossible, for however man's free will may be restricted, as soons we recognize it as a force not subject to law, the existence of lawecomes impossible.
	Only by reducing this element of free will to the infinitesimal,hat is, by regarding it as an infinitely small quantity, can weonvince ourselves of the absolute inaccessibility of the causes,nd then instead of seeking causes, history will take the discovery ofaws as its problem.
	The search for these laws has long been begun and the new methods ofhought which history must adopt are being worked out simultaneouslyith the self-destruction toward which- ever dissecting and dissectinghe causes of phenomena- the old method of history is moving.
	All human sciences have traveled along that path. Arriving atnfinitesimals, mathematics, the most exact of sciences, abandonshe process of analysis and enters on the new process of thentegration of unknown, infinitely small, quantities. Abandoning theonception of cause, mathematics seeks law, that is, the propertyommon to all unknown, infinitely small, elements.
	In another form but along the same path of reflection the otherciences have proceeded. When Newton enunciated the law of gravitye did not say that the sun or the earth had a property of attraction;e said that all bodies from the largest to the smallest have theroperty of attracting one another, that is, leaving aside theuestion of the cause of the movement of the bodies, he expressedhe property common to all bodies from the infinitely large to thenfinitely small. The same is done by the natural sciences: leavingside the question of cause, they seek for laws. History stands on theame path. And if history has for its object the study of the movementf the nations and of humanity and not the narration of episodes inhe lives of individuals, it too, setting aside the conception ofause, should seek the laws common to all the inseparablynterconnected infinitesimal elements of free will.EP2|CH12
	CHAPTER XII
	From the time the law of Copernicus was discovered and proved, theere recognition of the fact that it was not the sun but the earthhat moves sufficed to destroy the whole cosmography of thencients. By disproving that law it might have been possible to retainhe old conception of the movements of the bodies, but withoutisproving it, it would seem impossible to continue studying thetolemaic worlds. But even after the discovery of the law ofopernicus the Ptolemaic worlds were still studied for a long time.
	From the time the first person said and proved that the number ofirths or of crimes is subject to mathematical laws, and that thisr that mode of government is determined by certain geographical andconomic conditions, and that certain relations of population tooil produce migrations of peoples, the foundations on which historyad been built were destroyed in their essence.
	By refuting these new laws the former view of history might haveeen retained; but without refuting them it would seem impossible toontinue studying historic events as the results of man's free will.or if a certain mode of government was established or certainigrations of peoples took place in consequence of such and sucheographic, ethnographic, or economic conditions, then the free willf those individuals who appear to us to have established that mode ofovernment or occasioned the migrations can no longer be regarded ashe cause.
	And yet the former history continues to be studied side by side withhe laws of statistics, geography, political economy, comparativehilology, and geology, which directly contradict its assumptions.
	The struggle between the old views and the new was long andtubbornly fought out in physical philosophy. Theology stood onuard for the old views and accused the new of violating revelation.ut when truth conquered, theology established itself just as firmlyn the new foundation.
	Just as prolonged and stubborn is the struggle now proceedingetween the old and the new conception of history, and theology in theame way stands on guard for the old view, and accuses the new view ofubverting revelation.
	In the one case as in the other, on both sides the struggle provokesassion and stifles truth. On the one hand there is fear and regretor the loss of the whole edifice constructed through the ages, on thether is the passion for destruction.
	To the men who fought against the rising truths of physicalhilosophy, it seemed that if they admitted that truth it wouldestroy faith in God, in the creation of the firmament, and in theiracle of Joshua the son of Nun. To the defenders of the laws ofopernicus and Newton, to Voltaire for example, it seemed that theaws of astronomy destroyed religion, and he utilized the law ofravitation as a weapon against religion.
	Just so it now seems as if we have only to admit the law ofnevitability, to destroy the conception of the soul, of good andvil, and all the institutions of state and church that have beenuilt up on those conceptions.
	So too, like Voltaire in his time, uninvited defenders of the law ofnevitability today use that law as a weapon against religion,hough the law of inevitability in history, like the law of Copernicusn astronomy, far from destroying, even strengthens the foundationn which the institutions of state and church are erected.
	As in the question of astronomy then, so in the question ofistory now, the whole difference of opinion is based on theecognition or nonrecognition of something absolute, serving as theeasure of visible phenomena. In astronomy it was the immovabilityf the earth, in history it is the independence of personality- freeill.
	As with astronomy the difficulty of recognizing the motion of thearth lay in abandoning the immediate sensation of the earth'sixity and of the motion of the planets, so in history theifficulty of recognizing the subjection of personality to the laws ofpace, time, and cause lies in renouncing the direct feeling of thendependence of one's own personality. But as in astronomy the newiew said: "It is true that we do not feel the movement of thearth, but by admitting its immobility we arrive at absurdity, whiley admitting its motion (which we do not feel) we arrive at laws,"o also in history the new view says: "It is true that we are notonscious of our dependence, but by admitting our free will werrive at absurdity, while by admitting our dependence on the externalorld, on time, and on cause, we arrive at laws."
	In the first case it was necessary to renounce the consciousnessf an unreal immobility in space and to recognize a motion we didot feel; in the present case it is similarly necessary to renounce freedom that does not exist, and to recognize a dependence ofhich we are not conscious.
